title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @LiveWireBT
comment:
That sounds pretty bad.
"More quests" said no sane gamer with a job these days after playing a handful of games of the same type. Better and more enjoyable content, absolutely, but it's mostly always the same and it starts to appear lifeless even though the graphics are at the state of the art. And it makes sense when developers say that it's not just the (already terrible) churn, but now the churn or promotion of the inexperienced. It shows. I admit from 1990s to 2000s I was naive and played for graphics. But the bar for impressive graphics has become insanely high while acceptable graphics are now common but the (AAA) industry fails even more at delivering good stories. Sorry I have no time for that.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @silent_spitfire
comment:
Toxic positivity and intellectual dishonesty are the perfect terms for what's happening in the corporate world, but especially in corporate America.  not defending true hate speech and the like, but seriously, we are terribly 'soft' right now. I don't even begin to think that I've got the solution or have any idea where to draw the line, but it's worrying to think what end stage toxic positivity and intellectual dishonesty looks like.  

On the flip side, we've seen the extreme opposite, we experience daily life through an the 'Us vs. Them' lens--however valid, and necessary it can be at times to operate from that mentality, it has always resulted in someone being put down.  video games have influence, so I understand the caution and ridicule that developers face from the general public, but to completely disregard the developers and gaming community isn't cool..and when you prioritize profit over people, well...look at Ubisoft.  I used to be a huge Ubisoft fan, but man these last few years have been rough...I don't think there's a single Ubisoft game I've got favorited right now.  That's wild.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @SvetlinNikolovPhx
comment: I see nothing has changed during the past 12 years after I left. Whenever we shipped yet another mediocre game, the studio boss gathered us and gave a movie-grade speech about how great we were and how all difficulties have made us stronger, only to repeat the same mistakes and bad decisions all over again on the next game. And anyone disagreeing with this was delusional and free to resign because there is nothing like this great job anywhere in the world - as a C++ programmer, all you could ever do elsewhere was bank software - this was the mindset and the culture. I got into programming because I loved games and wanted to make games - after Ubisoft, I never wanted to play any game, ever again.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @alphawolfsrs3802
comment: I remember taken a trip to Italy with my family after playing Ezio in AC2. Took a tour and was asked by the guide how I knew so much about the area having never been there my response was Assassin's Creed. It one of my most favorite memories. Something I loved video games taught me something about real history that I would never get from a book. History was one of my worst subjects. Granted not everything was accurate but at least 80% was. The entire purpose of these games was educational but entertaining. Being an Assassin in a point in  time of history telling there story while educating the player on the era which they are playing. That was Assassin's Creed. I became so in love with this game that I decided that I would visit each location generally that each character played in. All the way to Origins in Egypt. Each time the amount of knowledge I learnt through the game and my own researched decreased. This turned one of my favorite memories and hobbies into something I felt lost itself in. But now I feel like its the Game who has lost it self.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @shnydtayne
comment: You know? Just yesterday I finished Saints Row The Third, and that was my first time trying a game from the franchise. It was SO REFRESHING! Men were masculine men and women were feminine women. You can run over, shoot, punch, etc. EVERYONE in the game, regardless of their sex or race, and they'd punch you back. The jokes were direct and unabashed. The weapons were raw and visceral, and the missions were completely bonkers. Games aimed at the male audience MUST be handled BY BASED, MALE DEVELOPERS AND WRITERS. Period. As soon as women or woke soyboys start developing these games, the quality goes down tremendously, and everything turns a lot less fun. And, no, it's not that I "only" like "toxic masculinity games". Even Mario and Kirby games are AMAZING to me. Wokeness is an entirely different thing. What's horrible about this is that wokeness is WEAKNESS. Nobody expects Mario to behave like Doomguy, because he is clearly a caricature. Mario is not super masculine or anything, but what's important is that HE IS NOT A WEAK, EASILY-TRIGGERED, MENTALLY-ILL, CONFUSED AND BRAINWASHED SLOB WITH NO BACKBONE either. That's what's wrong with wokeness. Oh, and Princess Peach is a normal cartoon girl, nothing bad in that. She is not a completely unrelatable, insufferable, narcissistic, disagreeable, heartless, spineless, bitter, misandrist bitch void of empathy towards anyone but herself, who magically got all her power just from being born with a vagina, like 100% of all modern "female heroes" we've been bombarded with since wokeness became a thing. Seriously, I'm fed up with this. I need games to go back to being like Saints Row The Third: larger-than-life stories and settings, great dialogues, funny and unapologetic jokes, great writing, great gameplay and a truckload of creativity. I hope everything woke dies off pretty quickly.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @greenblyat
comment:
This really ties up the general feeling I've gotten where people on the whole, not just in the gaming industry are so desperate to prove that they have some moral superiority or are "better" than you, jumping on any chance to prove that you're a bad person..over literally any word. Incorrect inflections, incorrect tone over emails/texts, "how often do you say retarded". It feels like the crabs-in-a-bucket metaphor where everyone is so ready to tear eachother down over nothing. 

Actually arguing for "people are people" and that everyone deserves a shot equally is somehow..bad? 

Not really all that relevant, but as someone on the spectrum..this kind of constant biting at other people over intentions and tone is frustrating to the point of nausea. What the hell?? This feels like it shouldn't be normal at all but it feels like it's millions of people all doing this and not even batting an eye. 

Talking anywhere online is exhausting. 

As for being on-topic with Yasuke and AC: Shadows..the tokenization of not only Yasuke as a person but Japanese culture as nothing more than "Pretty asian stuff"..it sucks. AC: Shadows had a good story right there. A servant to a Samurai, that samurai is killed by this ninja, compelled to carry that legacy. It could have been so easy to write a compelling story of perserverance in a completely different culture and thriving in it. But no. Hip-hop, cheap "mall-ninja" cosplay levels of attention to details, its just offensively boring...

God.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @christopherbusenkell8633
comment:
Dude, I about the same age as you.  I couldn't agree more.  It's baffling and it's been going on for a quite some time.  My sister works for a company that makes educational videos, regardless, their HR director, who we believe takes orders from a board of executives that believe it's important to buy-in 100% with all these trends.  So...to make sure they head off all the inevitable disasters of previous cultures and lost civilizations who weren't careful with addressing one another informally, they decided to make a rule that you cannot collectively refer to any group of employees as "guys."  For some reason, talking about all these stupid mofos who believe in this shit makes me really pissed.  All this shit is disingenuous, manipulative and isn't how healthy people communicate.  It's my opinion that it's fucking up these young generations, cuz after all when you beat these kind of stupid creeds in to kids minds and you do it repeatedly, you can't change your practices/ideologies later and try to brainwash the kids in a different direction.   Teaching people that your feelings shouldn't be hurt or that having obsessively thins skin about things like pronouns and making sure you tattle tale to your HR department instead of handling it yourself.  It has made this society in to a bunch of fucking pussies, or, actually when I was growing up it was acceptable to say Quit being a fucking fag and grow a pair!  If that hurt your feelings, then we'd proved our point.
      With regard to the word "retard," we need to have the definition formally changed.  In my lifetime, neither me nor anyone I was friends with ever used that word to describe someone who had struggles with their mental or physical development.  That's really cruel and fucked up.  Retard, it is my opinion, is used when rational adults are referring to a human being, who was willfully and deliberately done or said something so proudly stupid and baffling to onlookers that onlookers and people hearing the story all agree, that individual is retarded.  The person in question just goes about their business being retarded without being aware of it because it's what they are.  Like the dude I saw in the grocery store the other day and was testing out toothpicks and returning them to the box.  Or the girl that called the deli I worked at in college and to order a BLT for delivery.  She asked me if it came with bacon and I explained what BLT stands for.  I asked if she wanted the 8" or footlong and she asked which one was bigger...
     The rules for all this shit were laid out a long time ago and don't need to be changed, nothing will come from that.  But some asses do need to be beat, but those people will get their comeupance in due time.  Don't be vulgar in front of kids.  Be polite.  Err on the side of caution and be repectful of people you don't know that well.  Don't be a jackass, especially in public.  Be aware of other people's feelings BUT THAT IS AS FAR AS YOU NEED TO GO WITH OTHER PEOPLE's FEELINGS.  Psychologists will tell you, other people's feelings don't belong to you.  They're just words.

comment:
In my opinion, companies need to stop promoting accountants as CEOs or in creative management positions. They care about the bottom line. Not about the passion. Accountants are important. They should be there to council a passionate person, not control a company. 

There are accountants that are passionate about projects, don‚Äôt get me wrong. The vast majority of bloat in the higher ups only care about a bottom line and don‚Äôt care how they get there. If they are being told to play it safe and making their targets, then they don‚Äôt care what happens. They met their goal. 

It is only now the accountants are not hitting financial goals where stockholders are saying WTF. Only reason why there is change occurring at all.

comment: I had the "honour" to get in a discussion with one of "of those people". I mean on a professional level and surrounding, not on a personal level. They either can't or won't understand the complete logical reasoning you show here. They didn't with me either. Instead they turn around single words or phrases, putting them out of context or overdramatize them on purpose to make the conversation about you and what a bad, ignorant and willfully hurting person you are. Especially if you're absolutely not doing that. There is no way to show them, that you don't have any problem with them or their personal beliefs but with them forcing their views onto others and also destroying everything around them while doing so. Also they resort to personal attacks, trying to start shitstorms on you and try to professionally destroy you. All just for pointing out, that they do things that are either really oppressive, damaging or just plainly wrong and morally questionable at best (or a combination thereof). Really sad, that this is crawling through our society in all western countries in every aspect of life.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @gingashields
comment: Given that the real Yasuke was of extremely minor historical significance, and given the almost bottomless well of Japanese cultural and historical detail that could inform a game like this, what was the purpose of introducing this character? To be tokenistically 'diverse'? By their very nature these games traverse continents and cultures, and so achieve diversity organically. Or is it another example of the approach of 'appealing' to black gamers with a black character? Surely that's too nakedly condescending to be the case. So was it just to map on to other countries and their histories the current cultural obsessions of the United States and achieve relevancy that way for American gamers?! But that's just itself a form of cultural imperialism. So overall, it's just very very weird.

Entirely negative wtf you on about ? Outside of echo chambers and clickbait articles (and videos like this btw) everyone is hyped to fuck. We are all so excited for this game is looks amazing. It'd an unironic skinner meme "are my phony culture wars not actually based in reality, it's just a trillion dollar company pushing me into anger and hate because that gets the most clicks ?" "no, it's the devs that are wrong".

And it's the same shit. It's been the same shit since the internet began. You've got more clever with your language and terms, you dress it up nicely, you try to sound more academic, but at the end of the day, if it was a white dude instead of a black dude, y'all be lauding it for telling an interesting story while introducing something "us westerners can really resonate with". People like you and your ilk have done NOTHING with your life, just inherited what others who came before done. All you're being asked is to make it better for people who had less opportunities than you. title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @wondrouslyperish
comment: Too many things nowadays are considered "hate speech" or "harrassment", when in reality, it is simply free speech. Unless you are legitimately inciting violence or harrassing someone online, the bar for indicating these things needs to be raised. It's okay to have differing points of view and we must encourage individual thought, not discourage it because we nay not subjectively agree with it. "But it hurt my feelings" should not be a viable excuse to censor, ban, cancel, or attempt to manipulate media to potentially dissuade consumers one way or another. Shame on Ubisoft and many of these modern companies. Gaming, or otherwise. We may be "advanced" in many ways here in the West, however in the ways we have progressed in certain areas, we have regressed in others. A sad time to see something I have loved for 29 years in gaming, become so infected by prioritizations of every other thing besides quality storytelling, interesting characters, fun gameplay, and authentic artistic expression. I am looking forward to seeing this game and company get what is earned. Fantastic video and coverage of these events my friend üëç subscribed.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @chrislaws4785
comment: Even the most recent article from "The Gamer" TRIES to say that Yasuke shouldn't be removed and that its only "racists western gamers" who "dont want to play as a black man" that have a problem with the game. Its all LIES, the reason the game is GARBAGE is because of Ubisoft's IDIOTIC ideals and their willingness to LIE, TWIST and MAKE UP entire Japanese history with ZERO regard to ACTUAL Japanese culture. I mean when JAPAN ITSELF says it could become an international incident, then you SHOULD LISTEN AND CHANGE. EVERYTHING Ubisoft took "inspiration" from for Yasuke was written by a WHITE professor in japan who MADE IT ALL UP just to sell books. NONE of it is based on ACTUAL historical documents OTHER than the fact that there WAS a black man in japan named Yasuke who worked for Nobunaga. Other than that, ITS ALL LIES AND MADE UP. He was NEVER a samurai, he DID NOT play ANY kind of "pivotal" role in Japanese history or battle. If they wanted to have a black samurai, THEN THEY SHOULD have created a FICTIONAL character rather than using actual historical people. They SHOULD have simply created a FICTIONAL character who was a Black man and a member of the Assassin's brotherhood from Europe or even better a part of the original group in Africa established by Bayek, who travels to Japan in search of a piece of Eden and who becomes or disguises himself as a Samurai to make connections with Nobunaga and enlist other famous Samurai and Shinobi to the Brotherhood (just like Basim did with the Vikings in AC Valhalla). That would have been PERFECTLY FINE and even BETTER than what they have now and would have made PERFECT SENSE in the context of the overarching Assassins Creed storyline. It would have created a fictional character they could take ANY liberties they wanted to with, AND would have explained WHY a Black Man would have been in Japan during that time period to begin with. It would have waved away WHY there would have been little to no historical writing about him and could have EVEN played up why the writings about Yasuke that we do have are so scarce in real life. That he was part of the Infamous Assassin Brotherhood and made it a point to NOT be noticed and for people to not know who he really was and very few people even knew about him. It would have created this "Mysterious figure" that seemingly came from nowhere, done all these amazing things and then "Vanished into history with few daring to mention his name" sort of feel to it. NOW I WOULD PLAY THAT GAME!!! The MAIN issue continues to be Ubisoft taking actual people and turning them into something they NEVER WERE and NOT respecting Japanese culture and history.

author: @w_419
comment:
As someone in their 40's and who fell in love with gaming since the atari era it saddens me how fucking soft gaming companies have gotten and how they are more focused on pushing an agenda and pandering to the %1 than putting out a good product. It honestly still baffles me that this is where we are, I always imagined 2024 being a place in time were we would have immense technological growth, flying cars, holograms, vr gaming... etc. but instead we have assholes identifying as cats, pronoun patrols, safe spaces, cancelation of free speech, woke tv shows, movies and games and the threat of losing your job for sounding too "aggressive" or "Insensitive". 

"I'm sorry to say that the world has become a pussy-whipped, Brady Bunch version of itself, run by a bunch of robed sissies." -Simon Phoenix. If you know, you know.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @lawyerlawyer1215
comment:
I don‚Äôt get why they do it?

Is innnot simpler for them to just make the game time period-respectful and accurate and avoid the controversy?
Instead of having to align with news outlets to brush off the hate and call us gamers racists/mysoginist?

Happened with EA.  I always played battlefield games, since they released battlefield V and their president called us misogynistic pigs for calling out how wildly historically innacurate a women army squad captain in WW2 was, right after they had said it was going to be their most realistic WW2 to date.
Not only didn‚Äôt I played the game, I rejected EA forever.
Oh you insult me? Fine I‚Äôm not going to give MY MONEY to YOU anymore.

Same with Ubisoft, fuck your I‚Äôm not giving you money anymore.

Do they not read the audience?
80% of the gamers don‚Äôt want this forced nonsensical inclusion shit.

They don‚Äôt know the difference with us liking variety in character creation screens but not in forced characters.

When a game lets you do your own character, we want everyone to be able to enjoy the game how they want, I don‚Äôt care if some gender fluid Femboy in Los Angeles wants to play as very tall lady with rainbow colored hair and loads of make up on a single player gritty dark medieval fantasy RPG.

Let the boy/girl live whatever fantasy he wishes too.

Someone elsewhere might want to play as a lizard with wolf face and I can still make myself a human warrior than looks fitting to the world. Their immersion isn‚Äôt at the cost of mine.

But when you are making a pre-defined character that players have to use, you have to think about the setting and historical accuracy or at least most likely historical accuracy.

For example if it‚Äôs medieval age like and it‚Äôs a human warrior, then a big male. Because men are much stronger than woman and warriors where men because of this. If it‚Äôs fantasy race wouldn‚Äôt matter in this case,  but gender does because of the whole strength and sex thing.

If it‚Äôs other race like elves or reptiles gender doesn‚Äôt matters.

But making a samurai game where we are forced to play as a female when everyone who knows Japan, knows how submissive the role of the woman has been in this country since forever, still pretty much to this date they are way less advanced in that term than the rest of the world.

Or a black man when there was only 1 black samurai in their whole story and he didn‚Äôt made anything but exist.
Nothing interesting to his story but the mere fact of being black.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @SkpVgxl
comment:
Yasuke's character is just an excuse for some people to express racist views. Where was everyone when Ezio was portrayed as a 'historically accurate protagonist'? He's far from representing anything that actually existed during that time‚Äîthe clothing, martial arts, everything is fictionalized. Assassin's Creed has never been, and never will be, fully historically accurate. Nobody ever complained about Ezio, Altair, or any other protagonist, but now that the character is Black, suddenly it's a problem.

Maybe I‚Äôm the one overthinking this, but it feels like no one is able to see through these double standards. Are these people seriously going to pretend that assassins in history used the techniques you see in the game? I highly doubt it. These complainers probably aren‚Äôt even real fans of Assassin‚Äôs Creed anyway.

I just think it's sad how humanity seems so lost on issues like this.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @nomensch7664
comment:
why in balls are people saying it's a DEI/political thing!? 

Ubisoft has been making the same dogsh*t game for over a decade now, palatable only by people who'd call popcorn 'adventurous'. They have 3 gameplay templates(Sandbox/AC/Far Cry)  they apply to every game . No serious gamer would call AC anything but filler, in the same league as FIFA 20XX
Sucker Punch meanwhile made 1 (one) good-if-not-excellent game people have been asking for and scored big. People who enjoyed Ghost Tsushima will buy Ghost Yotei regardless of the protagonist's thigh meat/absence thereof. 

This isn't about DEI/Sweet Baby/gender/politics. This is about a bunch of delusional fans (finally) abandoning a franchise that has been going downhill for a decade (2013, AC: Black Flag). Thinking about it, if the protagonist's skin color was the reason someone dropped the franchise (not the repetitive gameplay, filler content, microtransactions, outdated mechanics, lack of focus, and general franchise exhaustion), then they might be a bit racist.

author: @mitchtupelo76
comment:
What sucks is Ubisoft is so very close to having a great set of games. I adore several of the AC and FC games, they just need to do a few small things:

1. Turn AC into a full historical epic series. Something which could be used in college history classes unironically. The immersion is by far the best and most unique part of AC. I can walk around Odyssey's map for hours despite it not being R* level detailed.
2. Abandon the preachy woke stuff. Fire Sweet Baby Inc, acknowledge their mistakes in this area, be transparent with fans about how it won't happen again.
3. Do a complete 180 degree turn on the game release side of things. Make all DLC free from the start, stop yearly releases. If this requires compromise in employment then so be it.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @GiantBUThead
comment: I genuinely do not understand what's wrong with ubisoft. For the last decade they've just been butchering their own games, which causes them to flop. Then when the players give them feedback and critisizm and tell them why it's not succsessful, they buy articles, bot comments and go on an all out war against their potential clients. And they lie not only to the clients but to their investors as well. And the complaints are more than valid, the forced wokeness aside, this specific game is wildly inaccurate historically and it's extremely low effort on the design and ironically is set in a nation where the people care deeply about their history and traditions. To top it all off, their previous flopped titles - star wars and the first ever quadruple A pile of dogshit were beyond terrible when it comes to gameplay and technical issues. Look i've never liked ubisoft or their games, even back in the 2000-2010's but this is just a disgrace. Ever since AC 1 people have wanted to see a japanese AC, hell even I who strongly dislike AC was kind of excited to see what it's gonna be, it's a match made in heaven, the biggest stealth game about assassins and the nation of ninjas. And they just shit in Yasuke the retainer, give him Zoro's sword from One piece and surround him with chinese buildings. For fuck sake.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @stykytte
comment:
I could say some stuff about Ubi, but I just know second hand stuff from a handful of people who worked for them, most of them have washed their hands with the company and moved on long ago when they saw the writing on the wall, so to speak. 

What I do have first hand experience with is not being allowed to use words anymore, words that I identify with. I have what are considered "learning difficulties" after a brain injury as a child on top of mild autism, I am descended from more than one actual African slave, and I am an absolute galloping fairy - But I am not allowed to call myself a R**ard N**ger F**got and this makes me sad. 

I want to take the terms back, but I am forbidden by actual bigots who refuse to allow me the onus of using words, as if they control the language, they can control the way people think, and if you control their thoughts you can control their actions. I may be a R**ard N**ger F**got but I am not an idiot and I know my history, I can see where this is going.

comment: I'll challenge the narrative on this. If you have a problem with people questioning words you say (which mind you there are words that are hurtful to people for one reason or another). Why can't you challenge your vocabulary level and find different words that are more descriptive of the problem or the issue you have instead of a jump to word that you have settled on because of your generation. I'm your generation as well and I understand both sides. However if I'm going to potentially make someone feel uncomfortable by a word I say, (and have prior knowledge that the word I'm using is more common to be a insulting word to a certain demographic) I will avoid saying that word and use my education of the English vocabulary to find different words and break those "generational habits". It used to be okay a generation back from mine to have your child go pick a willow branch and get whipped by it... in no way is that okay or should it have been... but that was during that generation... Doesn't make it okay.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @videogamer65
comment:
This stuff about meetings for not putting smiley faces on things is also happening at the indie level. 

I majored in directing for film and tv and a small publisher asked me to help them write a screenplay to adapt their novel as an audio drama. 

The creative director wrote the script and sent it to me for notes expecting me to just be a yes man. 

I wrote in red parts I felt were weak, I marked in green parts I felt were really good and had something interesting about them. 

Next thing I knew I was in a meeting with the owner about how I was being unreasonable and how I shouldn‚Äôt knock people‚Äôs art, and how marking things in red is threatening.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @patrickomeagher9868
comment:
I lived in Japan for 14 years and was married to a local for 10.  I have two teenage children who are dual citizens and spent half their childhood there.  I lived in Nara, Osaka, and Kyoto, where at least part of AC Shadows is supposed to take place.  I actually worked in Morinomiya for a few years, literally across the street from the grounds of Osaka Castle.  The Torii isn't just a gate to Shinto shrines, it's the symbol of the religion itself.  It's like the Cross for Christianity, the Star of David for Judaism, or the Crescent for Islam.  While they don't expect it of tourists, as a resident I was expected to remove my hat when I walked underneath them. In addition to Shinto shrines, they are erected in places of great sentimental importance, like around schools to protect their children, or cemeteries to comfort the souls of their loved ones.  The one pictured isn't just a monument, it's a memorial.  They wouldn't have left it broken unless it had staggering sentimental meaning. 
The vast majority of Japanese people I talked to said they didn't mind foreigners depicting their culture, many adding they considered it a compliment, as long as it was done respectfully.  One of my bosses that had studied in the US said, "It doesn't have to be perfect, but it should at least appear like you tried.   We are more than willing to give you an E for effort."  I think that's the same Torii that was depicted in the beginning of 'The Wolverine,' which started in a flashback to Nagasaki the day it was destroyed.  Most of the locals I talked to about the film had mixed feelings about the beginning, and were quick to point out what the filmmakers got wrong, but had a positive overall view of the film because you could tell the filmmakers tried to be respectful.  I'm not sure Ubisoft was using that very gate as a reference, but to use any broken Torii to prop up cartoonish characters shows a lot of ignorance and disrespect, and I think most people know respect is a pretty big deal in Japanese culture.

author: @Its-Me-JD-X
comment:
Not sure you will read this message, but I wanted to post it anyway.

As a former employee of another Big Studio, it is not just Ubisoft.
This happens at so many studio's around the world.
I quit my job because I couldn't take it any more.

Creative Freedom was more and more limited and it became all about doing "The right thing".
I questioned it and kept questioning it.
"The right thing that you are talking about is not what the gamers wants, it is actually what no one wants."

After multiple times of doubting decisions and trying to do my own thing.
I was left out of meetings more frequently, decisions were made without me, my work was slowly being scrapped/replaced.
When I questioned it, I was send away because "I couldn't understand."

If you ever want to hear about it, my story.
Feel feel to send me a message or respond to this. :)

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @JasonGamer25
comment: I honestly don't understand these people working at these companies... How is releasing a polished game a bad thing? I'm spending $100 on your game just to have, bugs crashes and issues.. a half-baked experience..and I am still expected to pay full price for this. How do people feel if they went to buy a $100,000 car and as soon as they drive it off the lot it breaks down? It would feel like shit right? Maybe even be a LITTLE bit pissed Well that's what it feels like.. maybe not at that price level but the concept is the same. I don't want to go home and have my free-time (which believe it or not.. is more important than the time spent at work to make the money to buy the FULL price broken games) and I'm spending half my play session asking myself 'WTF! Why isn't this working?!', or 'where TF is my character model?!' or 'why is my toon standing in a T-Pose on top of my motorcycle?! And why are they naked?!'. It doesn't make sense, if automotive, industrial, agricultural are held to the standards of if it's not working when sold you pay a fine and get sued, why isn't the entertainment? These companies should be held liable when the products don't work, instead we give them a year or two or three to figure it out? To patch it out? After spending that initial $100 the game works 100% as intended 3 years later.. when the game now costs $20.. maybe 9.99 on a steam sale.

comment: In the end, everyone of us has a choice. Don't like what a company (any company, not just game publishers) puts out? Don't buy it. Don't like how a company presents themselves, treats their employees etc? Stop buying from them. It's not always easy in other areas, Nestl√© is notoriously hard to avoid, but with games it really is easy. And as soon as the money stops coming in the companies will have to take a look at themselves or go bust. I'm not saying it isn't necessary to report on shit going on but as long as people keep buying nothing will change.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Viertekind
comment:
All right I get how BG3 is a financial risk, a CRPG in 2023 wasn't the projected favorite, but from a creative risk? It's a turn based top-down RPG. It's a VERY good turn-based top-down RPG, with more reactivity than a lot of previous entries to the genre could dream of, but they weren't recreating the wheel. They were just refining something they love.
Forget about the woke crap, that's all business now that's meaning has been lot through political wrangling. It's bad, but it's not the root of the creative problem. Anywhere where politics take precedence over quality and discourages HONEST discourse is gonna make crap. It doesn't matter what those politics are.
For a good creative direction though, I think just trying to EVOKE or SHOCK or take RISKS is also bad. Though maybe it's better than what we have. Taking a risk doesn't mean there's a safety net at the end of the cliff. Not all CRPGs are BG3. 
I think if you really want to creatively emulate BG3 then look at the context of it. The Divinity games feel like sketches with BG3 being the final masterpiece. There's an obvious enjoyment of CRPGs and D&D in the top parts of the company that bleeds into the game. Most games' purposes is first to be fun for players, and BG3 never forgets that. BG3 wasn't aiming for financial success (by how the game ran the company into the ground before release) nor to be a game for everyone. Yet, because it wanted to be a fun CRPG on all levels (visual, story, gameplay, roleplay) it GOT everybody to buy into what the developers loved about the CRPGs they played. A game like BG3 builds on the games that came before it. It isn't BG1, a trailblazer, but the current pinnacle of the genre. 
"Woke" games remind me of christian media. They're too concerned with being right than with doing WHAT SHOULD COME BEFORE ALL ELSE. A lot of Christian media lacks either the depth of hard-hitting questions because they don't want to show faith, believers, or god in a bad light. Which does the exact opposite by making them look gormless and shallow. Of course, C.S. Lewis shows that christian media with depth, artistry, and real joy in writing can exist.
Which forces me to believe that this Woke media is less an issue of politics, and more a loss of creative vision. Politics can be a great motivation for a creative vision, but if their beliefs are so shallow only to be broken by the softest of critiques, then I think those individuals need to reexamine themselves until what they truly want to make comes out. Or, in the case of Ubisoft, just letting people speak freely would be a nice start.
Which hits a lot of bits of what you said later in the video before I started typing but I wanted to rant too, dammit.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @CakeMelons
comment: What devs need to realize at a larger scale is that journos and activists essentially don't matter. What they say don't really matter. You make a game, you want ppl to buy and play it. Ppl, not journos or activists. And climate changed so, that ppl no longer listen or values media opinions or reviews. All this means, that while it's hard to get rid of ill willed individuals in workspaces, you shouldn't be afraid of what journos will say. What matters is connection with audience, artistic vision and integrity, technical competence. Journos and activist can shit all over you, but right now it will only draw more positive attention to your game, your audience will still buy your game and say thank you to you. Journos and activists have no power, no should they. And that's where responsible and honest content creators matter, they can bridge the info gap between audience and devs more effectively.

Mirage sure as hell wasn‚Äôt it because it was not rememberable at all in my experience playing it. 

 But when it comes to money and making sure you‚Äôre sticking to modern day DEI in everything you do‚Ä¶execs will choose those all day long. Same thing with Outlaws with the absolute piss poor effort that game is. It‚Äôs sad tbh.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @ninobasset8176
comment:
What I am going to say might sound a bit bitter, and I need to express how I am not disagreeing with the point made in this video.

But we also need to remember that Ubisoft became a commercial behemoth long ago, more in the hands of it‚Äôs shareholders than of it‚Äôs historical creative leads that left long ago, the same fate that blizzard EA Activision and others have met.

And what does that mean ? Well these companies are trying most likely to market themselves into American territory, yes there is maybe less population than in Asia, but it‚Äôs a wealthier population more open to occidental games (studios and ideas).
And let‚Äôs face it, most Americans don‚Äôt know/care about all these (important sure but still) details about Japanese culture, the half arch, the time of the year where Sakura blossoms is not the same that the one where rice is planted, etc.

All of that is very important to the Japanese culture, but in the American market mind, it‚Äôs shrines, sakura, and samurais, not much more.

These companies are trying to market to their targets, not being necessarily creative or respectful.

And guess what, even with the rants online, Ubisoft games are still selling high, creatively dull sure, but selling high.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @smoberley
comment:
This isn't new. Look what they did with Ghost Recon. They had a good hit with Wildlands and were pretty unique in that space. After having to apologize to Bolivia, they cranked out Breakpoint (5 years ago), which is bland beyond belief. Fictional setting, generic sci fi robots, and plenty ugly female characters too!. Super dumbed-down for casual audiences. That was 5 years ago. Simultaneously, they're blinded by the microtransaction money their competitors make, so they hilariously tried to turn GR into Overwatch (WTF?). 

They don't understand that if you want to make money off microtransactions, you have to sell the games *first*.

I found it mildly amusing that you banned that chatter for asking about your use of the word retard. It's almost as if you found it offensive that they found it offensive. Yes, in an ideal world you could've taken the time to explain to that little shit about how the world works but I also understand that some days you just don't wanna deal with that shit.

I don't know what was the right move there but you're in a position of power and influence. You might end up in an echo chamber where your videos end up preaching to the choir. That's fine, and maybe you're okay with that. Most things on the internet are so radicalized these days that one side cannot see the other.

Maybe I'm thinking too deep about a funny anecdote you wanted to share. I have no idea. Cheers and have a good day.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Kaveman.
comment: I do not think this has anything to do with Ubisoft, Sweet Baby, or anything else of the sort. This is a fundamental societal issue. I think that the "pre-woke era" was very insensitive and intolerant to many social issue and as smaller societies joined the global community and became more aware of one another, people pushed back against it. I also think that what we see now with the "woke era" is an overcorrection in the attempt to remedy that by tipping the scale in the opposite direction towards fear and oversensitivity. Now there's a push-back to that too.  The balance between two extremes usually lies somewhere in the middle, and from a larger perspective, all of this looks to me like nature's attempt at finding that sweet spot. As for whether we'll actually reach that balance, I do not know. After all, societies are constructs and they are no longer architectured by human nature (the masses), but rather by a class of people who think themselves to be better.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @sjcgill
comment:
The push to a february release is intentional. The game will fail, it's not in question, the problem now is who gets the blame. By moving it to a February release window they can blame the competitive release schedule for the games failure and brush the rest of the criticism under the rug the way they have already done. 

This is just a PR move to protect those who are living the fantasy that toxic dudebros are causing the game to fail. Ubisoft will make some press release about how the DEI side of the game was never an issue and it was just a bad release schedule, and the PR team will get hit with the redundancy bat. 

Meanwhile the people who pushed this ideology will get a cushy new title to work on and the cycle will repeat. Ubisoft is in a death spiral, and without divesting itself of the cancer at the core, they will not escape it.

author: @romansmitskyi1368
comment: I work in IT, however, far from gamedev field, however, I feel the common pain regarding most of software companies becoming so toothless that sometimes it becomes a disadvantage. Regarding Ubisoft - my hill to die on is that AC3 was last good game in Assassin's Creed Series. I couldn't bring myself to complete AC4 since it was released until now, and I would like to say that it feels like a cartoon. Plot is completely unserious, making you feel no emotions at all. I'd say, both plot and gameplay are empty. Being a pirate, plundering, there is much death in that, but even when you board the ships in the game, it didn't look to me as something that would instill fear in those poor sailors. Try watching Game of Thrones S7E2, where Euron Greyjoy's fleet is boarding his niece's ship, this is a proper plundering and massacre. Even the Legendary Pirates in AC4 felt like Loony Tunes characters. Shame.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @XBushWookieX_Of_Order
comment:
2 things to take away here. You the consumer have the power to dictate the games that are made the way you dictate is with your wallet. I refuse to do preorder‚Äôs because so many games are broken. I wait to buy this so trusted gamers I watch play the game and I review it along with them. Sometimes opinions line up other times they don‚Äôt always. It means I have an honest impression and a honest review vs the ‚Äúprofessional critics‚Äù 

2nd Thor and amazing fellow, developer and streamer has tons of videos teaching and encouraging people how to make games. It‚Äôs not for everyone but don‚Äôt be afraid to. Games made by gamers are made with love and passion. 

3rd bonus fact gamers don‚Äôt care the race, the gender or the pronouns but when that is the only selling point and the mechanics, story and graphics look and act worse than a ps1 game with tank controls or worse. It‚Äôs garbage. They could replace the samurai character with  Miyamoto Musashi it wouldn‚Äôt matter if the gameplay was still horrible, the time period is still incorrect, they still use Chinese structures in place of authentic Japanese buildings and architecture, and still released the Torii gate statue showcasing the bombing of Nagasaki. I wouldn‚Äôt touch it with a 10 foot pole and would still harp on it like everyone else. Plenty of great minorities and gender neutral characters have existed. Just in much better games and stories where that is an interesting tidbit not the whole selling premise. Sargeant Johnson will forever remain one of my favorite characters in Halo and had some of the best dialogue. I think some gamers actually enjoy him as a character than Chief because chief was meant to be a neutral character you could implant yourself upon no matter who you were by not revealing his face and that was stated by bungie all those years ago.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @wotnvideos
comment:
A lot of foreign people miss the entire point about the Sekigahara Teppoutai (Sekigahara Gun Corps). They are not a reenactment group. They're larpers who thought it would be fun to dress up in period costumes but also shoot guns at the same time. There is no such thing as a Sekigahara gun corps in real life, they made it up. That's the entire point of why Japanese people think it's so ridiculous that Ubisoft stole their flag - Imagine if a game about the US civil war decided to include people dressed in Star Wars costumes. Ubisoft's devs kept droning on and on about how accurate and faithful to history the game is at first (they started pulling out the contradictory "it's fiction, it's just a game, we never meant for it to be accurate" bullshit later) and this was just one of many indications of how full of shit they were.

And it should be pointed out that Hashimoto does not understand Japanese and was ridiculed by everyone when they started to post Google translated gibberish in an attempt to "prove" that they could. Pathetic.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @dragondelsur5156
comment:
When using Japan as a setting, you have to be very careful if you claim it to be historically accurate and that's what doomed Assassin's Creed Shadows the moment it stepped through the door (well, aside from having a useless misinformed cultural consultant that is), like, how can you claim your game to be representative of the culture whilst also using a destroyed Tori gate as a marketing stunt? How can you claim your game to be historically accurate when you use Yasuke, an actual historical figure, as a workaround for your female protagonist (which wasn't the first time they do this, look at Alexios/Kassandra and the two gendered Eivor)? How can you be so dense when responding to the criticisms of actual Japanese people?

The more I see these controversies, the more I'm convinced this game only exists to leech off of Ghost of Tsushima's success, but they didn't see the beautiful landscapes, the attention to detail on the culture, conflict and time period they represented or the fact that this game even pushed tourism for the real life island of Tsushima, all they saw was an opportunity to bank on samurais because that sells. No wonder they jumped ship out of Tokyo Game Show or else the public would've reacted with the scorn they deserve.

I left Assassin's Creed a long time ago, and I don't regret it one bit, and if Ubisoft falls, I'll be there to watch them crash and burn.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Egon_Freeman
comment: Being provocative is great when you're CREATING your market, or carving your niche out of it. It polarises people - and when nobody knows you, it makes you memorable, and while some will scoff - others will cheer you and _make you money._ But once you HAVE that market or that niche, and you're a household name? Being provocative is horrible, because it polarises people - some will cheer you, but many others will scoff and _lose you money._

If I am not mistaken, the first AC entries respected the main known historical elements, but had rewritten parts of how those elements got there. In that sense, I don't mind some historical inaccuracy. "Uncovering the real history" is part of the AC universe, after all. But I don't think that is what AC Shadows is doing here. It seems that it lacks more research and understanding of Japanese history.

Having an African character in feudal Japan doesn't bother me. But making him a playable character  with warrior like mechanics? I don't know. I would have just had the female Japanese character and have Yasuke as a supporting character or something (maybe playable in a future DLC).

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @atb2674
comment:
Based off prior corporate bungles  they‚Äôre releasing AC in February, despite it pitting themselves against better competition, bc their fiscal year ends in March. In a rough analogy corporate version of ‚Äúgirl-math‚Äù: 
if ur a grocery store and u order X amount of an item but don‚Äôt sell it by a determined time period, it‚Äôs considered a financial loss for that period, even if u can and do sell it in the next period.

So by similar logic all the money spent producing and especially promoting AC Shadows throughout FY2023-24 will be a huge loss for the year‚Äôs bottom line. It‚Äôs common practice across many industries to line up movies, albums, new product lines, and so on right before a fiscal deadline to help with accounting and boost numbers last minute

Ubisoft WILL release a bad or unfinished game instead of delaying it until proper execution. I bet their train of thought is along the lines of we have to recoup something if anything from this mess & with people saving up money for the wave of games to release in Feb they might attract a few sales from people curious about the bad hype.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @XandateOfHeaven
comment:
The criticism of the creative liberties taken with Yasuke and Sengoku Japan do feel disingenuous for two reasons. Firstly, Yasuke despite being basically the only black samurai actually was an important figure at the time, because he was a in the retinue of Oda Nobunaga, who is literally the most important figure of the time. He was also witness to his assassination, and its not totally clear what happened to him after. So independent of the novelty of Yasuke being a black samurai, he's a pretty good choice as a main character because of his proximity to these events. He was also a real person, so the criticism of his inclusion as being "woke" is nonsense, that's just people expecting black characters to be excluded so the game doesn't appear "woke."

Secondly, it terms of creative liberties taken with the portrayal of Japan at the time, this is pretty standard for an Assassin's Creed game. 

None of this would be an issue if the game was good. The problem is we don't expect it to be good because AC games have gooten formulaic, soulless, uninteresting, full of heavily padded quests that ars all the same, lacking in mystery, creativity or challenege. Obviously Ubisoft is going to deflect these criticisms and say its an anti-woke backlash (and some of it is), but it doesn't matter if the game is actually bad.

An interesting juxtaposition is Fromsoft and Sucker Punch compared to Ubisoft.  Fromsoft borrows heavily from historical architecture so much that you can often figure out the exact building they used as a basis.  They are incredibly detail oriented, and that is when making a fantasy world!  Ubisoft just grabs things at random with zero effort to understand the culture and history they represent.  That just shows how lazy and out of touch the developers are.

Ghost of Tsushima proves that a non-Japanese developer can make a game based in Japanese culture and do it well.  Ubisoft has no excuse for failing to even approach the standards of Sucker Punch.

comment:
I left Ubisoft in 2022 and man, it was the best decision. They were already going down with what they had to release back then (even worse with Heartland being dropped after ~3 years).
Oh and yea, since the controversy, we had to take DEI and LGBT trainings/webinars to change our way on how we see those things. This is probably why that said dev mentioned the emoji. You could change how other people address you (it was a joke that you can literally have anything, like firelord or whatever, it just had to be approved by HR) and women who identify as men or men who identify as women, could go to the bathroom they identify with and nobody said anything otherwise it would be bad. I had to stop using urinals because I had women coming to the bathroom and I wasn't feeling ok. 
So yea, overall, toxic culture and bad games made in collaboration with sweet baby, ruined them.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @supereldinho
comment:
Remember folks:
Nioh's main character was a white samurai and was based on an actual person, narrative liberties notwithstanding. Everybody liked William. 
Even the game Expeditions Rome features a Maori playable character because such people historically did exist in ancient Rome, and another one of your companions is a woman who actually will be subjected to proper gender bias of the time and be denied several privileges that men enjoyed. Hell, you can play as a woman yourself who despite some narrative liberties will also be subjected to the same bias, such as being denied the right to hold office and required to enter a political marriage. The game as a whole got many of the period details right, even down to how genders are being addressed, i. e. dominus for men and domina for women. 
The point? 
There's a difference between being anachronistic but still respectful and being out-and-out revisionist and insulting. Ubisoft clearly likes to be the latter.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Iwatoda_Dorm
comment:
1:20 as much as I don‚Äôt want to back ubisoft for their past games, I could not find any legitimacy to this statement that other‚Äôs are making of historical inaccuracy in specifically architecture. Pagoda‚Äôs have existed since early Asuka period (538-710) due to the rampant buddhism and in major part due to one of the officials Prince Shotoku interest in the culture. 

I ran into many twitter accounts reposting a picture of a 3 tiered Pagoda which to my knowledge is historically accurate as can be, since a famous 3 tier pagoda- the Kojoji Temple made during the Muromachi period (1333-1573) was made around the time when Yusuke was known to be alive 1555-1582~

I think people should get off their high horse when it comes to these things because clearly- no one actually does their research to find that these rumours stirred because of Tatami Mats found in the preview trailer being square and not rectangular, with the image of that journalist website being the image of the pagoda with the title ‚Äúhistorically inaccurate‚Äù

The half torii gate was insanely crude though and in poor taste, but honestly I couldn‚Äôt imagine them having done that on purpose. They probably legit thought it looked cool at the time and used less resources to sculpt. Outside of that, they better just change it or discontinue it‚Ä¶ that is‚Ä¶ _woof._

I hate how corporate has turned appreciation of a culture fully realized in a 3d world into a shit show like this, I genuinely don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs anyone‚Äôs fault outside of the higher ups in ubisoft. This game will always look great visually, and will probably play like ass, like all assassins creed games have been.

comment:
In my opinion, what the Studio needs to come back to their glory of Splinter-Cell and Rainbow Six Vegas, Watch Dogs or Division 1 - they have to lay low... leave out ANY releases for 1, maybe even 2 years. Focus on the internal comapny. Focus on the Service for your live-games. Focus on educating your employees. Get them experience with more games, more engines, more tech. Upgrade your hardware for your top tier developers and focus on the things, that where told by the community the last 3 years. Make a team to point out, what is important to the gamers. And dont try to "ignore" or "ban" the things, instead try to put them into your team and remove the obsticales. If something is too much.

And than make a comeback... no assassins creed. nothing that is "new" to your team, no cooperation-stuff like Star Wars. ... bring us something we know the studio for. Bring us something your developers are giving their lifeblood for. Give us something spectacular. Something like a comeback of Splinter Cell... mabye Rainbow Six: Patriots. Maybe For Honor 2... And foucs on that game only when it comes out. Major priority for the next 3-6 months. Give us content... no p2w-crap or NFT sh*t. CONTENT. Listen to your players feedback and maybe then you can go in other directions.

author: @calebharch7229
comment:
This may be quite the hot take:
Console and PC gaming is a primarily male dominated market, and a niche market at that.
Mobile gaming is where the majority of female gamers play, and where the majority of money in the games industry comes from.
Therefore I believe console gaming should pander to the stereotypical male, think of it like playboy, who buys them? Men, but I'm sure many women work in the publishing, editing and many other sectors at playboy, but what you don't see in playboy are disgusting overweight whales with gross skin conditions, why? Because it's aimed at a primarily male audience!
When women come into the console games industry, it is so important to understand who their audience actually is, and that their audience doesn't get offended.
This isn't just aimed at female Devs, but also those whiny little soft cocks too.

Tldr; know your true audience.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Lucifishy
comment: Honestly, mixed feelings about this video. The tirade about being mad that somebody was made uncomfortable by you calling something retarded (y'know, a derogatory ableist term) was weird. I get it, slip-ups happen, but the correct reaction there is "yeah, product of my upbringing, my mistake, sorry about that," not, "I'm banning you for being slightly uncomfortable." That tirade was just... fucking weird, dawg. That said, there were some good and reasonable takes - misogyny is bad, obviously, but overcorrection to the point of discouraging physically attractive body archetypes etc is wild. Games like Baldur's Gate prove very well that you don't need to tone down your characters physically in order to make good/meaningful designs and representative ideals.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @B1tPixel
comment:
Ubisoft was once my favorite game company.
Prince of Persia, Far Cry 2 and 3, Rayman, first couple of Assasin's Creed, Splinter Cell.
Then they fucked everything up with their greed and some baffling decisions.
"Oh yeah, let's fucking release 12 assassins creed games in the span of 5 years with 0 improvements to gameplay, that'll sell great! And lets even make them into a shitty GaaS, because why not.
This Far Cry thing, the gritty sandbox shooter about horrors of losing humanity? Lets turn it into a funny farce! Look, here's a funny dog! Haha!
Prince of Persia? Rayman? What the fuck are you talking about?"

And now this. I was dreaming about japanese Assassin's Creed as a kid, playing as a ninja and not as a fucking samurai, whose whole philosophy is face your enemy, killing people from behind is a big nono, punished by disgraceful death. They already have the framework, just make japanese decorations and use ninja clan as a big plot point - and they're golden. But NO, they had to make this shit. I don't care in the slightest that mc is a black guy or some shit like that, it's just so fucking obvious what they should do to make a good game and they purposefully did not do it.

I hope AAA game industry crashes and burns to the ground in nearest future. Fuck them.

comment: This management issue isn't just gaming, it's a current trend in most industries. This created many headaches which caused downtrends in sales. This in turned caused layoffs across the board which they seemed to want to get rid of the higher paid employees with institutional knowledge to have them replaced by juniors, contractual employees and students. If you're seeing any company lose touch, or pivot in a way that "welcomes" a wider audience and pushes away their core audience. This is probably happening. The high turnovers are forcing to consistently have new employees without true roots in the company to make poor decisions.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @ObeyCamp
comment:
Ubisoft has been refusing to listen to gamer feedback for a long time.  What this confirmation of their refusal to listen proves is that Ubisoft thinks they're foolproof, and that their games will generate a substantial profit no matter what.  They think their young gamers and casual gamers customer bases, and the way they charge nearly double-price for their games and sell them for about 100% actual value when they're "on sale" will be enough to outweigh the disapproval and sales losses of more seasoned and discerning gamers, and for a long time that has been precisely the case.  

However...

With this issue becoming bigger and bigger, and with Ubisoft mismanaging the development of every game they make at this point, I think the worm has turned, or, at least, it's very close to it.  Thank god.  

It makes me so sad to know the Ubisoft I used to love is dead, but it is.  The developer who made some of the best games ever, is just gone‚Äîa shell of their former selves, hollowed out by greed.  Killed by an addiction to income at any cost.  But that's important to recognize.  This isn't the Ubisoft we love and remember‚Äîthis is the replacement, the anti-Ubisoft, and we need to let it die.  

Do not give Ubisoft money, no matter what tricks they pull.  
Just don't do it.
Understand that if you do, you will be ripped off and you'll be supporting the kinds of people who want you to "be comfortable not owning [your] games."

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @CurzonEve
comment: "RE.TARD.ED" is the first word I learned.  Before incompetent political correctness swept through culture, generations of speech therapists, teachers, and counselors knew that children with learning disabilities and speech impediments incapable of processing the mouth movements to form communicable syllables could most easily process that word.  Try it yourself.  "We."  "tod."  "ded."  Those three syllables not only require minimal mouth movement, but when vocalized around strangers by a small child, ALSO TRIGGER HELP.  "Police" and "Please" are similar enough that those two words are the most important vocabulary words for a mute or disabled child to be able to get out in case of emergency.  Raise your hand and repeat "wetoded plees"  until someone helps, or contacts the police.   40+ years of training, education, speaking drills - I live the fantasy of so many people with learning disabilities - being largely indistinguishable from anyone else without close scrutiny.  I despise politically correct people who have robbed the most vulnerable of us all with easiest and most effective tools to get help when we need it.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Axterix13
comment: Have to say, not being able to provide feedback as a developer would just be... horrid. When I was in game dev, I'd routinely give my opinion on things. Sometimes, this would lead to changes. Biggest one of those was where the designer and I spent multiple afternoons completely revamping a big chunk of the game's menus. And other times it wouldn't, but that's okay, too. My job was to code, theirs was to design. But the simple fact is we talked, because we all wanted to make a good product. To not have feedback like that would be like to not get any bug reports when my code didn't do what it was supposed to. That would just be a moronic thing to do.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @CaptainTopkek
comment:
I miss the times when people would just play a game for what it is and not concern themselves about stuff like "oh, it's a black character", or "uuuh, you play as a woman, it must be woke agenda". I mean, don't get me wrong, I also hate how the world is changing into with this woke bullshit, but... just play the fucking game for what it is, bruh...
I know... Ubisoft is starting to get soft, and clearly working with the woke agenda in mind, every year fucking up their releases, and when it comes to ACS, the only word that comes to mind is "silly", at most... but I'll still play the game. The fact that a black guy is one of the main protagonists for me is just silly (based on cultural accuracy, and not from a racist standpoint), but then I remember... Games are fantasy... WHO GIVES A FUCK?
Play the games for what they are... Games... Fantasy... and bitch more about the lack of mechanics, bugs, etc, and bitch less about what biological gender or skin color character you're playing as.
When Lara Croft games came out, I didn't see any bitching about that.
I'm not defending Ubisoft in any way, I worked for them for 5 years, like... 10 years ago, and yes, things have changed, but it just seems like if people would stop giving a shit about certain issues, the gaming community would be less filled with hatred. Silly times we live in üòÇ
Just play the game and have fun. Worry about bugs, level design, SFX, VFX, AI behavior... These are the important issues in game development.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @jgunner280
comment: The character pitch and Me-to collision actually makes a lot of sense, although is certainly a tragic turn. Suddenly the artists and pitch behind making your character, and the manager or higher-ups that move it forward, all don't want to be "that guy" that picks a highly attractive looking female. I can remember in the DarkSouls design works there was a passage discussing how Gwynevere 'broke' from the design norms in certain way, but the artist was just "a little too proud" to argue with (or something like that), and they made it work. She was an illusion and token of hope and respite anyway, so they didn't have to make her a great demon creature or knight anyway. Still, that artist did the exact opposite, and the companies don't expect that anymore over here. It makes more sense that the history of the industry makes them more scared at an individual level to present this stuff, rather than just chalking it up to "DEI said to make them ugly". I mean they're definitely still feeling that pressure if companies like SBI are breathing over their heads, but its more likely rooted that no male artist is gonna make an idealist image, or even a female artist making a power fantasy will then take it to some male middle-manager that doesn't want to feel weird about elevating that, etc. That really sucks, but its cool insight I wasn't considering before.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @SomeYouTubeTraveler
comment:
I remember back when I was a kid in the 90's, and "Christian stuff sucks" was the joke everyone understood.  The stereotype was that Non-Christians had all the cool stuff, which could be edgy and fun, and Christians were stuck with what was considered to be watered-down, vanilla, "safe" stuff like Bibleman and VeggieTales.  In the stereotypical Christian media no one could say bad words, no one could be attractive, the committee-approved morals had to be front and center, and it was generally all constrained by over-sanitization on every front.

This new culture we have now is constrained by the same religious fervor, the same moralistic over-sanitization, as the "Lame Christian Content" of the past.  The only difference is _which_ words are considered unforgiveable cusswords.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @BeersYourFriend
comment:
When you said retarded, I didn't think you did anything wrong at all, because 99.9% of us knew what you were talking about. Do people really think that when people say something about someone or a mass group of people are retarded, somebody actually thinks a particular person using said word are targeting actual medical retarded people? No! Absolutely not! It's not even a medical term anymore. Nobody who says the word retarded thinks about people who have a severe mental issue. We've been saying that word for decades. This cancel culture nonsense needs to stop.

From Wikipedia:

*Pejorative: (A pejorative word, phrase, slur, or derogatory term is a word or grammatical form expressing a negative or disrespectful connotation, a low opinion, or a lack of respect toward someone or something.

For Example:
- Much like today's socially acceptable terms idiot and moron, which are also defined as some sort of mental disability, when the term retard is being used in its pejorative form, it is usually not being directed at people with mental disabilities. Instead, people use the term when teasing their friends or as a general insult.

Rosa's Law: (In the medical world, medical retardation has been replaced)
- Despite not typically being used in official context, "mental retardation" was still written in many of the United States' laws and documents until October 5, 2010, when U.S. President Barack Obama signed into effect S. 2781, also known as Rosa's Law.[12] The bill changed references in federal law; the term mental retardation was replaced by mental disability. Additionally, the phrase "mentally retarded individual" was replaced with "an individual with an intellectual disability".[13] Rosa's Law was named after Rosa Marcellino, a nine-year-old girl with Down syndrome. She worked with her parents to have the words "mentally retarded" officially removed from health and education code in Maryland, her home state.[14] With this new law, "mental retardation" and "mentally retarded" no longer exist in federal health or education and labor policy. The rights of individuals with disabilities would remain the same.[12] The goal of this change in phrasing was to remove language that may be considered derogatory to communities. 

If I say something is retarded, my mind doesn't go... "There are people with a medical and mental disability, so now I'm going to say this word retarded to someone". "Hey, you guys are retarded!". "YES! I got em!". Are these guys going to go home thinking that someone calling them retarded, now think that they may have an undiagnosed mental disorder, who should all go to the doctor for a checkup? NO!

Legendary Drops, nor does anyone else on planet earth, uses the word retarded while also thinking about about someone with a disability.
It does not happen. It is a slur.

Another slur word many people say is, "Blind". Cohh Carnage brought up this topic a few years ago, after people got offended in chat, after he used the word blind. Cohh said that this is ridiculous, who will continue to use blind. Cohh, nor does anyone else saying "Are you blind?" are actually thinking about an actual blind person, who is offending someone. And, I back Cohh up on that claim. "How did you miss that shot? Are you blind?" It's used all the time.

This cancel culture crap has got to stop. People get so upset over the most "insane" things today. Everyone gets so easily offended, and I'm sick of it.

Yes, I said "insane." Can you believe that? How could I possibly say such an awful word? Wow!
- Don't you dare tell me you are offended by using the word "Insane".
- Do you think when I say someone is insane, now means that I am at this moment thinking about someone locked in a cell, with a straitjacket on, who is jumping and slamming into padded walls, for hours on end? NO friggen way! Sure, I just technically did think about someone who is insane (schizophrenia, and other psychotic disorders right now, but my version of insane can be perceived in many different ways, depending on the individual. You're mental process about the word "insane", visually to you, may be absolutely perceived so differently to how I visualize the word "insane".

Lighten up people! It's why jokes suck today, because comedians are afraid to say what they want to say, that is 100% due to this cancel culture world we now live in, and I absolutely hate it! Nobody is happy anymore with anything said today, and it sucks. Am I allowed to laugh at anything anymore? Can I not have fun and laugh with words somebody says, or words that I say? What on earth is going on with people today? Let someone say something, and move on. Don't try to correct someone. No one likes a person who constantly corrects someone. It is annoying. If you are one of these people who is constantly correcting someone, and are wondering why you have no friends, well it's because of your behavior.

I've said enough here. I can't believe I just went on-and-on ranting over the words retarded, blind, and insane.
Oh nooo guys... Maybe I'm insane? Dun dun dunnnnn! Maybe I need to go see a doctor to get a checkup.ü§£

Great video as always, Legendary Drops!
- Cheers & Peace!üçª

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @havcola6983
comment:
The "Historical inaccuracy" complaints against the Assassin's Creed title falls pretty damn flat to me, I have to say. Where were these complaints with the Dr Who levels of accuracy we saw in Origins, Odyssey and Valhalla? Ever since AC1 it has been filled to the brim with anachronisms and a cultural pick-and-mix attitude to gear and clothing, equivalent to someone today wearing crocs and lederhosen. Historical people are aged up, down, their location, status, looks and mannerisms rewritten to fit the narrative. AC2 had us fly a Da Vinci glider and drive a tank in renaissance Rome! In Origins we fought a Minotaur! 

The historical accuracy in AC: Shadows is the same as it has ever been. 
Some of the sudden demands for perfect accuracy can be explained away with pure Gell-Mann amnesia. 
The rest... well. That's probably not actually why they're mad, is it?

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @danielpanchenko4315
comment:
Liked the video, came from extremely well made Warframe video,  but hated the 11:30 part so much. Hate it every time when a big youtuber/creator goes "look at this industry! Look! Also let me bitch about misusing the word and someone noticing, let me just sneak that into my whole righteous speech".
Words change meaning and have different weight over time. Queer was offensive before queer community made it their own. Retard was a funny insult until the world became more aware of the illness.
You were using it before and it became a force of habit, everyone gets it and it's not a big deal. Same as no one would care if you accidentally called a trans person by the wrong pronounce not knowing who they are. No sane person will hound you for that, not talking about twitter folk out here. 
My apologies, but as a 100k+ YouTuber it just comes out wrong when you start bitching about people being on standby to be offended by you specifically. You said retard in chat and one viewer out of your whole stream became concerned? And your response was to ban them, because the question offended you so much? 
Preach what you preach. I agree completely with the overall message, managerial decisions to kill project after project with marketable "diversity" is depressing. But don't glue yourself to the issue just because you used to say retard when it was funny, and now you are hurt when someone doesn't understand this as a joke like you did in your time.
I'm focusing on the "hard R" statement so much, because it's what a lot of youtubers seem to be transfixed on. If you treat your viewers like all they want to do is beef with you on these topics, the overall atmosphere will be that. For all I know that one viewer you banned just wanted to educate you on the modern meaning of the word.

author: @Mr.Grinns
comment:
Your capitulation to the rhetoric is what tears apart your own argument.

This "im not saying you should be able to go around saying anything" is the very core of the issue as to why this sort of victim mentality has spread so heinously. Because people like you put limits on speech, put limits on "what people should be able to say" even if its only passively. Free speech, freedom of thought, is the right to be offended, the right to feel hurt. Any limits you place on that instills the seeds of tyranny upon people. It instills the idea that "hey i should be careful about what i say or else i will face structured consequences". Its nonsense like that thats the driving force behind the very issues that you're supposedly condemning in this very video. There is no room for restricted speech in civilized society. People should be able to say what they like, where the only consequence is that others see them as an asshole. That is the true freedom of thought that our society was built upon

i've been saying for years that the woke side of entertainment the audience sees, the contrived, amateurish, fan-fiction like approach to plots, the mary sues, the stereotypical characters and situations, is only the tip of the iceberg.
the real issue that's plaguing western entertainment is the behind the scenes, where woke means diversity hirings, toxic positivity, protected categories, fear mongering and such. they have established a set of priorities where competence is not in the top spot, but rather demographic is. and so what happens when you cast people instead of hiring them is you enable incompetence to thrive, and if you throw in the witch-hunt like climate that makes people afraid of speaking up, you basically get why we have a problem.

i.e. we have been selecting our architects on the basis of how pretty they look, now our houses are crumbling and we're still puzzled about why that is.
