Outlaws was shit not because of diversity (Star wars always been diverse) but because it was just bland ubisoft sloop.
Shadows is bad not because of diversity but because it is missing Diversity, specifically Japanese diversity and accuracy.
Freaking weirdos on both sides of the gaming community currently and it just makes absolutely no sense whatsoever. Look at Baldurs Gate, probably the MOST diverse game we seen in decades, if not ever, and it was a massive success cause people could be whatever they wanted and it was amazing.

What sickens me most is that it is often the overcorrection that gets things to be sour; Ubisoft with all its massive rape and harashments, Blizzard with its greed theft and murder, and we dont even need to mention EA cause holy shit.

Bottom line: Diversity isnt the problem. Greedy companies trying to shift the blame is.

In regards to "safe content" this is something Cyberpunk 2077 despite its issues was able to manuver around well. 
There is literally a side job you get where you have to track the source of where a particular snuff film was edited so it can be traced back to those who made the footage because it contained the child of a wealthy buisnessman. This shows the dark and gritty nature of Night City alongside the lives of people in that city

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @A_slewOfbears
comment:
Ok.. hear me out, cause i think alot more people agree with me than they think. 

I feel as if you take a step back and just look at it from a simple gamers perspective. Take all the DEI, and hurt feelings out of it. I think having a game like AC-Shadows telling a story about a (most likely) fictional character in early japan, is a good thing for freshing up the gaming genre space. As long as they can actually get the culture correct (hense the half Torii gate meaning) i dont think theres a priblem with telljng a story about a fictional character, inside a fictional story based driven game. ITS ALL FOR FUN, and i think thats alot of what people forget. 

How many culturally innacurately depicted games did we play when all this "words hurt" shit didnt matter when we were either kids... or teenagers playong LAN parties on Halo 2.   ALOT

Because we all knew it is fictional characters inside a game that is made to play and have fun. 

I understand why the Japanese people are mad about the inaccuracies of the game culturally, but as the game in a whole, i think people need to take a step back and realize once again that its just a game... and that video games arent real. They are ways to tell fictional stories, with fictional characters, that you, the player, has the ability to control. 

Just like the feeling of when I (AND MANY OTHERS) read lord of the rIngs, and then played your first good lord of the rings game on PS2/xbox.  You could control your favorite FICTIONAL character inside your favorite universe. 

So, as far as assassin's creed shadows goes, i think that Yasuke is an awesome fictional character to play as, seeing how other than Afro Samurai is the closest thing we have gotten to play Yasuke. As long as the damn company that makes it doesn't shit on the culture the certain character is coming from, if they are going to attempt as much historical accuracy as possible (with adding a character like yasuke in) they need to do it with respect.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @PROTOBLUES90
comment:
Gotta funny Story about management and it was from my first job. 

A younger me Applied for a goodwill that was opening near my home, and after being accepted I was put in donation receiving. My job was basically to assist people in bringing in items they wished to donate and writing them a tax slip if they wanted it. The problems started when the people that process the donation in the back of the store stopped doing their jobs and just played on their phones. I had to keep up with my job, and leave my post to do their job so I could keep doing mine. I was getting reprimanded for not staying at my part of the job until the manager told me I should go home and cool off, I told her to shove it and that I quit. 
Flash forward a few days later and I get a call from the nicer manager at the store and get offered my job back. I declined. Flash forward 6 years later and I am applying for a goodwill in a completely different state and the topic of my prior employment comes up. I explain where I worked and what I did, turns out my goodwill became famous for having it's entire staff fired and replaced a month after opening day, a week after I quit.

That felt.. bitter sweet. Some of the people there didn't deserve it, but unfortunately scorched earth is far better than letting it feaster in these situations

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Li1t
comment:
Ubisoft's problems are nothing to do with black samurai, using the wrong architecture, using banner without permission, or whatever. You're just trying to pin the company's issues on the bogeymen you've been crying about. I dont doubt that others have been crying about them too, it makes the news, but it's hardly why the Star Wars game did poorly. It did poorly as the gameplay was shit. You're saying the developers are saying the problem is the management not listening to criticism? The developrs are the ones who pulled banners wholesale from real life groups without permission. The developers did a lot of the stuff you're talking about, not the management.

The problem is that the people calling the shots don't focus on the game being fun. It'd be possible to make a wildly historically innacurate game if they just focused on the game design. Instead they pad it out and water down the gameplay, focusing on using as much of the player's time as possible instead of tigh and rewarding game loops. Every game must be bigger than the last one, 100 hours but without enough gameplay for more than 10 or 20. All money spent on art assets, not enough spent on game design / combat / balancing. 

You're just working back from "game is shit" to suit *your* angle and claim to be right.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Alex92TnT
comment:
Ubisoft did this to themselves. The toxic work environment behind the scenes that blew up into sexual harassment allegations played a part, but still only part of the problem. Ubisoft used to dump on PC players, openly admitting they cared less about them and thus ports were buggier. They rushed games, made decisions to move games into annual releases, emphasized quantity over quality. 

Comparing a Ubisoft game to Baldur's Gate 3 is an insult to Larian. Larian spent so many years working on one game they genuinely cared for, worked with the community in early access for years, listened, and it shows. Ubisoft just tries to push out as many games as they can as fast as they can in a vacuum. The fact that they want to blame all this on their workplace culture changing is hysterical. I don't take their reasons seriously, it sounds like more old men whining about consequences of being justifiably cancelled for their actions. 

The cracks were showing before that happened. Assassin's Creed Unity came out before that happened, and it was the buggiest thing they made. Far Cry has seen reused assets like Primal's map being borrowed from 4, and New Dawn borrowed from 5. They made the decision to start pushing for always-online games, said that gamers should get used to the idea of their games just disappearing from libraries, embraced horrible DRM, and treat every IP like it's a slave. 

They intentionally nuked Skull and Bones early on. Their downfall is on them, well-deserved, and I won't miss them because I want to play games made by people who actually care, not some corporation that just wants to make more money for their shareholders by turning art into a conveyor belt of mediocrity. Let this company die like it should have earlier.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @ArthenMagnar
comment:
About the HR part and also the CEO himself telling you that the company is not pushing any agenda, from the Ubisoft news page:

"Beginning February 1, 2021, Sikka will join Ubisoft and report directly to Ubisoft co-founder and CEO, Yves Guillemot. While the role is intended to be flexible, a major focus for the new VP will be to establish and implement a comprehensive diversity and inclusion roadmap to support Ubisoft‚Äôs company culture at every level."

In a introduction interview (also on their website) she stated that she will have entire strategy as a DEI VP and will also be looking how it can be implemented in the production cycle.

"Another area I‚Äôm looking forward to exploring is production. I understand the pressures and deadlines of preparing a product and shipping it, both from an entertainment and tech perspective. I‚Äôm curious to explore what it truly means to make inclusive games at Ubisoft, and how we can push forward in that space creatively and inclusively."

She reports directly to Yves so him saying that there is no agenda being pushed... that's just the kind of lie, that should guarantee you a way out of business. 

Having a DEI VP in your company means that in fact you have a predator that has more power than the CEO. Stocks seem to confirm that and now you also know from the developers that they basically have their hands tied due to the fear of loosing their jobs. These people are basically too scared to be creative like they were with the Far Cry series. The same situation, the same fear is present at many other corporations, banks are unquestionable leader in all this.

As for the AC Shadows delay, I bet the production issues are not the main driver here. Adding more features always means adding new bugs. It is an endless development loop. You don't need to believe me, just ask any developer.
 
The company is basically showing us a middle finger while saying to take few months for cooling off as they will not change anything on their side.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @NevermoreNeverAgain
comment: The delay is actually Ubisoft cutting their loses and trying to bury the talk. I mean, people will be too busy with Kingdom Come Deliverance and Monster Hunter to talk about AC: Shadows and the timing seems like so deliberate... with the Ghost of Yotei announcement - game is set in the same time period of Sengoku Jidai, they have a badass female character and it's Sucker Punch, they will show love and respect to the people and culture of Japan, after all, who in modern times even heard of Kurosawa and they had a whole homage to his movies in Ghost of Tsushima! Meanwhile Ubisoft can't even depict something as simple as a season with plants from three different seasons in one picture... When Sucker Punch bends history it's for good reason, they're adapting the time period and trying to make it feel like the samurai and shinobi stories we are accustomed to but when Ubisoft does it, there's no good reason behind any of it. Even choosing Yasuke as a protagonist is headscratching given that they had no problem inventing characters for previous games and now all of a sudden they take a historical figure and make it into a protagonist? And for what reason exactly? Ezio wasn't real, Cassandra and Alexios weren't real, Edward wasn't real - all they had to do there is interact with actual historical figures for legitimacy and now that's not enough! This whole mess is just stupid...

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @MrMarcusIndia
comment:
To be fair, we don't actually know if it was Sweet Baby Inc who recommended the black protagonist for a game set in feudal Japan.

However, I'd argue that if you're a cultural / DEI consultant who fails to point out how inappropriate that is, along with the Chinese architecture, etc. then they simply aren't doing their job. And that's the best case, the nicest thing we can argue for them!

DEI done well is a good thing. Avoiding offensive and lazy stereotypes, thinking about the wider audience, etc. is a good thing. Besides Tom Cruise, I had no idea that there even were any non-Japanese samurai. But there were, apparently. Therefore, having a black samurai as an NPC, even as a major character, would be both historically and culturally accurate as well as interesting. But to make them the main character is simply a bizarre choice, one that is likely to alienate a large market of Japanese gamers and beyond.

But these people aren't concerned with "interesting" (or fun for that matter), they just have a misdirected agenda that they're trying to impose on everyone else.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @The_Thracian_
comment: Awesome analysis brother, I have worked in Ubisoft as a Character Artist in the Bulgarian studio, which is supposed to be with a Balkan root and Balkan people are not easily offended or cry about everything, not even mentioning not being Politically correct. But what amazed me was to see people that were afraind to speak freely as if we are in communism being afraid to tell a joke about the system because you might go to labor camp, or dissapear, and we`ve had that here in my country. And it is really shocking to see how comformative people can be, and its safe to say that is the no:1 formula to root out all the talanted people and people who have potential, because the conformative people get top positions for being "nice" and greasy, and tend to passively hate on the "naughty" talented people because that is a defense mechanism of the weak in order to secure one`s comfy position and countinue shoping expensive beers from E-bag (them lazy asses), and pay off their mortgages. And that being put in perspective you have a studio incapable of creating art anymore, and art is meant to be free in the broad sense of being real, dirty, offensive, dramatic, gritty, and whatever else that encircles the words free and authentic and is part of the real world. For anyone working there and finding sense or recognising what im saying, stay for maximum of 3 years, build a portfolio, and leave, there is a big wide world out there of investors and companies that actually want to make something good, with the ever expanding tools like unreal, unity etc. more independant studios are popping up, you will have more money and feel better about yourself. The biggest relief is not being forced to bend over to the souless ones. And fu+k me, toxic positivity is living fu+king Hell, its much much worse than standart toxicity. I hope this turn of events for the likes of Ubisoft will lead the gaming market, and companies, in a better direction.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @dmitrydyachenko1144
comment: what I don't understand is how is not listening to your fanbase, an actual source of your income, and people of culture you're trying to represent in your game and instead focusing on forcing western ideologies into your game that has nothing to do with them considered a good financial move? Like, isn't financial growth a main focus of any business? Your audience that is going to be the main source of your income is the most valid source of information you need in order to make a good game. I always thought that to be as obvious as it could get. Take a look at black myth as an example. Passionately told story with a character the entirety of china is familiar with from their childhood. Or an even closer comparison, ghost of Tsushima. You've got all the source material laid out for you, you just need to layer fun mechanics and gameplay on top of it and you've got yourself a great game.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Ed_Crane
comment:
Like I said on Asmongold‚Äôs video about it, at the end of the day, game companies like Ubisoft are and always will be merchants 

They are not political, they don‚Äôt give a shat about ideology, they only took that ¬´¬†woke¬†¬ª route those past few years because they have been mislead into thinking that is what players wanted

Obviously no one wanted this, and as it starts reflecting on sales, in a bigger and bigger way game after game, game companies are also realizing they were wrong 

Now that being said, the situation is indeed dire for Ubisoft, and yet I am pretty sure all it will take is one good game

If the next AC or the next Far Cry or the next whatever (Splinter Cell..?) is a success, and if they manage to adress and fix some of the recurrent criticism they faced, then it will be alright

Because we as players are not white knights either

No matter what Ubisoft did, no matter what Ubisoft thinks, if they start making good games again, people will buy

EA is amongst the most hated publishers in the industry and yet people keep playing their games because they are good, or good enough

author: @VenraeLOL
comment:
As someone who has been playing a lot of R6 Siege - and the issues that game has been having this year - hearing this explains A TON on why the game has been a shit show.

Also, on the topic of AC Shadows being moved - I firmly believe the announcement of Ghost of Yotei played a role in that decision. Ghost of Tsushima is such a beloved game, with a similar setting and similar mechanics as modern AC games - to have its sequal announced so close to a game shrouded in controversy's release is begging for even more criticism.

Given how entrenched the culture is at Ubisoft, I dont think there is a path to redeption without a takeover and restructuring of the entire company. Even with their stock being at an all time low - they seemingly refuse to change course.

author: @Kaiza5150
comment:
Ive been watching the Gaming industry for at least 35 years now. Im 47 btw. In the last 15 yrs, well before Me too was a thing, Corporate suits took over the industry and the companies involved. These suits are as singularly driven as any Wall St. Shark. Whats worse, is they very much despise the people that buy the games they provide. We are wallets to be bled dry of every nickle, then discarded.  The effort to turn "Players into Payers" is so obvious in almost every facet of gaming now, I wish more people were disgusted with it as I am.

I find it Comedy gold that they point to critic scores, in an effort to celebrate themselves.  "Popular gaming sites" like IGN, PC Gamer and others, hate the average man that buys these products, as much as the suits, but these companies are all collage activist driven, with their "They/Them's" Misogyny! White straight male Evil! beliefs. And they are all Fluff girls for the gaming companies. If you dont know what a fluffer is, look it up.  All this has been going on for a good long time, but average ignorance and good will to fall for the same tricks, keeps these suits in business.

I hope Ubisoft goes belly up. Sad thing is, the people at the top always have a golden parachute and another comfy gig right around the corner. Skill at generating money promises an easy life... at the cost of your soul.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @simonm1233
comment:
There has been a lot of misleading stuff out there in regards to how upset people in Japan are over this. Like people saying politicians were up in arms, when really it was 1 very rightwing guy who's party is not taken seriously by other parties in Japan. And is asking for inquiries into this matter were thrown out. Also the petition that was going around could hardly be considered a massive amount of upset. Add onto that, that nearly every video on YouTube claiming people in Japan were upset over this, was from channels with an agenda, which is ironic considering these are often the same channels that criticize SBI for having an agenda.

All this has been fairly easy to dig up so maybe look a little deeper than your biases might initially permit you.

Edit: Also just because there is mass criticism and ratioing of videos, which i agree there is. Doesn't mean it's coming from those (the Japanese) who this actually impacts. Your statement doesnt prove anything. If anything it would make me want to dig deeper and maybe question what about my content attracts a certain demographic of person. You have had some very questionable takes and a quick view of your comments sections shows you do have quite a few of what many would consider toxic gamers. At best your channel also attracks a lot of people who are just against any inclusion and hide behind the, "if its good inclusion its fine". All this rage is from a trailer for a game. Just like the person who created the Steam list of games that SBI was involved in. No one talked about the fact that when he was interviewed, he admited to not playing most of the games on the list. Which changes a lot of the narrative and why SBI when after him.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @GeometryEX-hp9zs
comment: Ubisoft has always had optimization problems. But the peak of graphics quality was probably in 2016. After that, it was stable and declining. The overall decline in the quality of 3A games actually started in 2018. Repeating the same content over and over again. Like Call of Duty. But Ubisoft and EA are actually the same. Their games have begun to lack the development and maintenance of the basic code layer. This even affects the operation of the program. This shows that they lack not only senior engineers, but also programmers to help them solve code problems. These problems are sometimes fixed half a year after the game is released, and sometimes they are never fixed. It is not difficult to imagine what kind of working environment developers face. No criticism, no opinions, just follow the instructions of the leaders. Then this trend will gradually become irreversible. The core developers have left Ubisoft, and I don‚Äôt think they have any way to recruit them back. After all, they have done an even worse mentorship program and recruited people who have no game experience to make games. This disaster has reached a point where they are bankrupt, and it is obvious that management is not aware of this. Assassin's Creed Shadow is a disaster. I have to say that if they made another statement that this is all fiction, players would be able to accept it. But from the moment they claimed that this is a historical figure, it caused public outrage. Whether it is development, design, or marketing, it is a disaster, which is enough to capsize the ship.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @nacho4288
comment:
Man...stop kidding yourselves. You give absolutely zero fucks about historical accuracy or misrepresenting Japanese culture. None of you know anything about Japanese culture outside of anime.

Yasuke is a person that existed. Whether he was a samurai or not is debated, but his existence is not. AC hasn't been historically accurate ever, much less recently. Apple of Eden, Animus, alternate history, centuries-spanning war between Templars and Assassins? Come on. Now recently you can fight gods. 

Nobody cares about accuracy until a black guy is where he "shouldn't" (even though he's valid in being in the time period). What's the issue with playing as a foreigner to the game's setting? Like, actually? Especially when there are TWO protagonist and the other is a native Japanese. Oh wait, she's a woman, doesn't count.

It truly stresses me out how much of a stink is thrown by gamers about everything. Ubisoft is not a good company and it's steeped in actual bad shit like misconduct allegations, but the idea that their worst sin is having a "woke agenda" and are "infiltrated by Sweet Baby Inc." brother you are a grown ass man. Wake up and stop blindly hating everything with a label whose meaning has long since been blurred.

For God's sake, the interviewee cited ASMON-fucking-GOLD. Is this a bad joke?

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @chucknya1448
comment:
There's basically 2 kind of devs at Ubi nowadays: few older people that stayed at Ubi that know how to do stuff but don't have time to keep in touch with videogames (which gets super problematic in leadership position) and a lot of newbies fresh into the industry since everyone that was experienced and competent all disappeared since a bit before the pandemic.

* Pay is worse than everywhere else.  
* People are bored from doing the same things by working in many titles within the same brand
* Problematic projects that sucks from the initial concept and you know that you're technically punished financially to work on them because there's no chance of profitability 
* Editorial was messy before and probably still now but publisher (especially north america's office are utterly incompetent and they are never accountable for their mistakes)

I believe the studios are mostly doing better now if they survive their current predicament but the projects messing up right now are all those that started during that dark period.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @deathmancerp
comment:
Queer, AuDHD, Leftist with a lot of POC, gay, and trans friends and family. only bringing up these things to give context to my perspective.

aside from wokescold twitter lefties, the broader left tends to find this stuff annoying at best and gross/ alienating at worst. When it comes to lefty critiques of media, the argument is for representation, not tokenization and this has been long identified as out of touch corporate lib shit that literally nobody is asking for, nor wants, and I think that that can be seen in how nobody actually really defends it. It's good to have games that explore concepts of toxic masculinity, racism, sexism, etc. such as games like wolfenstein (explores male childhood abuse and the struggles men go through as a result of that conditioning, along with racism and sexism, of course), God of war (toooons of interaction with concepts of toxic masculinity and generational trauma), Red Dead Redemption 2 (deals with racism, masculinty, sexism, etc.), and that dialogue doesn't necessarily have to be perfect either, but at least it's happening and goddamn can it hit hard (ngl, wolfenstein legit still sometimes make me cry), and I think people even still appreciate characters who just happen to be of other demographics (Ellie from the last of us 2 just so happens to be a lesbian and I feel like that has very little impact on people's ability to connect with her). That being said there's also still tons of enjoyment in getting to play as a roided up beefcake badass who oonga boonga bonks, tears, an crushes his way through hordes of unfortunate enemies that made the mistake of being in the way after gunther chugged his 5th pre-work out of the day. There's appreciation for all of it, but companies like Ubisoft don't realize that they take away that opportunity for dialogue and inclusion by turning communities of real people and real experiences into one dimensional heteroflexible Jimtilda, patting themselves on the back, and pretending like this is what communities are asking for, then silencing anyone that they're claiming to represent who try to say that they're either not being heard, misrepresented, or having their culture stripped of it's identity, treated like a neat gimmick, and even disrespected (anyone who has any familiarity with japanese history would know that mixing their stuff up with chinese architecture/ history is wiiiiild, aside from genuinely being kinda racist).

Video games are an art form and when it's treated as such, that's when you see success. A good character should have depth and be able to be identified with, regardless of your background. I'd like to think that, even if you don't pick up on all of the subtext, good characters and good stories implant concepts that you take with you and think about after you're done playing the game, saying that it intention isn't to just let loose and annihilate swarms of nids and demons haha. It's no surprise that your company might start dying when you produce things that nobody asked for and nobody wants, since there's no actual audience and nobody wants to buy your game haha.

comment:
People think ubishit turned woke just now. But I had experienced that in watchdogs legion and far cry 6. Even watchdogs 2 too if you really focus on some elements of the story.

Games aren't supposed to be made with a political message. Games are supposed to be fun. An escape from reality. 

I had fought off ubishit sheeples in reddit comments when i raised by criticism for watchdogs legion and far cry 6. I warned that ubishit is going down a path that would be disastrous for them. A few years later, i stand corrected.

You know what i would even play a woke game or two. But then there comes the same repetitive checklist type of games created by ubishit. Even if someone is to overlook the woke pandering, the games are just shit. If you focus on the rpg style AC that started with origins, at max you'll play origins and Odyssey. But when you come upto Valhalla, you'll be so bored out of your mind due to the mind numbing checklist type of games.

I didn't even bother with Mirage because i was just done with ubishit.

But with the AC shadows controversy and the game play of it, I am actively wishing for ubishit's downfall.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Hubloom-n9t
comment:
Honestly, I feel like a lot of the hate directed at games with Black main characters isn‚Äôt actually about the game itself. Whenever a Black character takes center stage, it seems like they are unfairly targeted. I genuinely can‚Äôt recall a single game featuring a Black protagonist that has been appreciated without some backlash. It feels like people latch onto every little mistake, searching for something to criticize, often before they‚Äôve even given the game a chance.

For example, when Miles Morales was introduced, there was a wave of hate focused on the art style and various details in the movie. I can't help but think this mindset is deeply rooted in racism. Why weren‚Äôt there similar complaints about any Ubisoft game until they introduced a Black character? They‚Äôve used the same design choices and gameplay elements in many of their other games, so why the sudden scrutiny now?

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @TheHiddenOne690
comment:
This was such an insightful and well made video. It put into light just how poorly & toxic Ubisoft are run. It's painful for me because I am an Assassin's Creed creator. I love Assassin's Creed. NOT Ubisoft... Seeing them make these terrible and stupid decisions just doesn't make sense. The torii gate, the zoro sword, the chines architecture, the stolen flag, the hip-hop music. It's almost like why? Why do this? Everything could've been avoided if they just sat down and thought about it properly. I don't mind Yasuke. I find the character interesting. But I am not blind to the fact that once again, this could've been avoided had they just added a japanese samurai. It's almost like they are intentionally making bad decisions after bad decisions to essentially create angry interest.

You mentioned it in the video. Ubisoft can't cannot take risks anymore without offending workers or higher-ups, so they play it safe as shown with the mediocrity of Star Wars Outlaws. I remember just how brutal and risky the Pazzi conspiracy was in AC2. I remember Far Cry 3 taking a risk with Citra ra***ng Jason Brody during the hallucination, I remember how risky AC1 was buring religous books.. Risks risks risks. Well written stories and actual passion was put into these games. Origins was the last AC game that truly was memorable to me. That was 7 years ago. I liked Odyssey, but i'm not ignorant to admit it wasn't an amazing game. But 7 years later, there isn't 1 ubisoft game that I enjoyed.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Helyssea
comment:
I have something to say, pardon my english if i make mistakes. It's not my native language.

I have worked with Ubisoft as a test player several times , they have a program you can sign up to in France ( i don't know if it takes place in others country but i would assume it does).  
Basically goes like this , you are called on your cell phone , a date is chosen and they give your Ubisoft connect a special "game" to remotely play from your home on one of their computer. 
A bit like teamviewer but you only control the game and can't alt+tab which make sense. 
You are in a discord call with other testers and some devs during the testing , it usually take place on a 6 to 8 hours period, 3/4 hours before moon and 3/4 hours after.
I won't say which specific games i tested since i signed a non disclosure agreement. They make you play a very early game version with loads of missing stuff, for exemple no dialogues, musics,no hairs on characters etc.
After every 3/4 period of play time you are asked to fill up a questionnaire and gives vocal feedback to the devs you are with.

And i can say this, after several times working with this company i stopped answering to playtest invitation. I litteraly feel like NONE of the feedback i gave were used or taken into account , had a conversation not too long ago with other playtesters and they felt the exact same way. I really feel sad for this company , 10 to 15 years ago we were proud to have a huge succesful company that came from France and made good games. We are sad that it became what it is now...

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @stalkholm5227
comment:
We saw something similar to this with Star Trek Discovery.  A contingent of the community disliked DISCO because they thought it was "woke," that's a fact, but a lot, lot more of us were frustrated with the poor writing, poor characterization, and overproduction; Paramount lumped the "I don't like DISCO's poor writing" in with the "I don't like like DISCO's Gay people" folks, and made it sound like the ONLY complaints were about politics.

It's true that some people hate all things "woke," but those people can't be used as an excuse to ignore or dismiss other, more substantive criticism.  I never gave a damn about Star Trek Discovery's casting, I cared that it wasn't very fun to watch.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @herbertyoung5000
comment:
I'm Asian. I used to be part of Gamergate. Your video encapsulates why I joined, and why I disassociated with that whole movement. 

You make many EXTREMELY legitimate points and criticisms about Ubisoft (i.e. its toxic corporate culture, its mediocre games, and the faus pax it made involving Japanese culture). But for all those legit points, you then fall into the trap of labeling depictions of 'diverse' and 'non-hot' characters as problems. As if including women and black people are a mistake.   

Diversity is not the problem. You understand that the true evil isn't diversity and political correctness, but the big capitalists using those things as a means for profit; thus causing diversity to be expressed poorly. That's the enemy there. Not fucking DEI, woke or 'Sweet Baby Inc', or whatever words 90% of your commenters use every time they see a skin color/gender they hate, or anytime they see a woman that's not 'hot' enough. 

I'm going to say it: regardless of however Ubisoft might fuck up their game with cultural inaccuracy, Yasuke is cool. He was a big tall foreigner thrown into an environment unlike his own, and somehow rubbed shoulders and found favor with one of the most famous historic figures in Japanese history, during one of the nation's most infamous warring periods. He's an interesting character, and god forbid we have ONE samurai game set in Warring States Japan where you can play a historic non-Japanese character. 

I'll say this too: I won't ever touch Star Wars Outlaws, but anyone who thinks the protagonist looks ugly must REALLY not like 1980s Sigourney Weaver. She looks fine. Not every single woman in video games or Star Wars has to look like a supermodel or fucking bimbo. Not that it's bad when they do (Lady Dimitrescu and Bayonetta, by gawd), but not EVERY woman. If you want hot women in your games all the time, you can go browse the Hentai category on Steam. 

Also, I'll add this as a fellow millennial. If someone at my workplace throws out the word 'retard' on the regular like punctuation, I'm not going to be comfortable associating with the guy. I'll give him the benefit of a doubt, and maybe ask him to tone it down. I'd even be fine if the guy excuses it as a personal tick, while making an effort to stop using the word. 
But if the guy doesn't just refuse to stop, but gets ANGRY at the mere suggestion to stop? Then I'm assuming the man has no sense of respecting people. Just some angry asshole who thinks everyone's out for his ass, because he thinks it's impossible to criticise something without dropping a slur for autistic/neurodivergent people.
The oppression in a workplace like Ubisoft's is one thing. But in saner everyday spaces, it's called being fucking polite. If you think the opposite of toxic positivity should be equally toxic negativity, then you're just on the far end of another spectrum of assholery.

But now they are not laughing. We are only growing, and our idea is spreading. Inclusivity and diversity are cancer. Speaking truth is becoming the new gospel. Away with political correctness.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @CacheTaFace2
comment: I think you might be reaching a little far into the 'DEI ate my lunch' jar there. Blaming HR for games being bad or boring is a little like blaming the bus driver if other passengers are being annoying. It sucks that you had bad experiences with that shit (I did too), but there are more obvious places to look for explanations (or cast blame). There are systemic problems with the way big games are in these companies (process, tool, management). These processes were tuned to make games that suited a particular business model which doesn't work as well anymore, but they can't adjust because the companies literally grew around them. They need one of two things to fight this amount inertia A) really exemplary leadership (haha) B) a better idea, and that's not happening either. That's why they are chasing trends the way they are, they're just waiting for somebody to come up with the next big thing. Pretty sad in Ubisoft's case considering their history. So yeah, TL;DR: I would look at organizational inertia, inept leadership and inability to lead the market before point fingers at HR and DEI stuff.

author: @insparetime5
comment:
Great video, you‚Äôre a real stand up guy!!! Now that I have your attention and real quick before you ‚Äúban the shit out of me‚Äù which sounds like a tagline for Ex-Lax, I‚Äôd love to hear your response. That is, unless you‚Äôre a coward.

To start off‚Ä¶ Oof. 22 minutes of a grown man throwing a temper tantrum. Yikes. And you recorded, edited, and uploaded it. Okay.
For someone who harps on people being sensitive, overreacting, and being hostile towards freedom of thought. You really are the perfect evidence to your own point, huh? Though, I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs just a product of your upbringing.

You know what else was a product of your upbringing? A blatant avoidance of introspection and mindfulness. Have you ever contemplated why that word may offend someone? I know you prefer to regurgitate the same tired, philosophically absent catchphrases from 2017 rather than form a personality or perspective, but try your hardest to think why it can offend someone.

I‚Äôll help with 3 hypotheticals to inspire your child‚Äôs brain in a grown man‚Äôs body to become mature, respectful, and empathetic (though I‚Äôm sure you define these traits as toxic positivity)
1. They have a family member with an intellectual disability. If they‚Äôre low-functioning and require constant medical care, the parents‚Äô love and sorrow are evident as their child is hospitalized frequently, undergoing painful treatments, and unable to play just like all the other children. Financial instability also looms, as they struggle to afford medical bills for someone they love.
2. The person you banned was on the spectrum. They loved your content, felt like they were a part of the community you built, then you ‚Äúunconsciously‚Äù said what you did. They would probably feel pretty dismissed and blindsided. They just wanted to escape reality like everyone else, have some fun watching games. Instead, you used a disability to describe something negatively. Attributing a word to a negative. Remind you of anything? hint: Someone in 1963 had something to say about doing that same thing to marginalize others.
3. The horrifying history of how people with disabilities were treated. Learn the reason these laws were passed. PARC v Pennsylvania (1971), Mills v. Board of Education of District of Columbia (1972), O'Connor v. Donaldson (1975), Youngberg v. Romeo (1982), City of Cleburne, Texas v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc. (1985), Ford v. Wainwright (1986), Olmstead v. L.C. (1999), PGA Tour, Inc. v. Martin (2001), Spector v. Norwegian Cruise Line Ltd. (2005).

If you won‚Äôt respond can you block me so I don‚Äôt get your temper tantrums recommended anymore? Thanks!

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @boss2329
comment: For those that aren't familiar with the significance of the half torii gate, torii gates are an important icon of Japanese spirituality. They're typically placed at the entrances to shrines and mark the transition from the mundane to the sacred. When the second atomic bomb was dropped on Nagasaki, it destroyed one leg of the torii gate placed in front of the Sann≈ç shrine and left the other half standing. Since then, the half torii gate has become a monument to the loss suffered by the Japanese people and the resilience it took to rebuild after the bombings. Ubisoft took that historical monument and flippantly used it in their promotional material without any understanding of what it represents, they just thought it looked cool. Truly a new low.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @dragonhale2026
comment:
People arent only prepared to catch you using a "bad word" in the moment, that is not even that offensive. They SCROLL UP and use the SEARCH FEATURE in chats to get people banned or in trouble for everything they say.
They actively want to get others in trouble for the smallest things, and they actively want to "feel offended" and they actively want to save others that dont even need saving from evil with that obnoxious hero complex that they suffer from.
They have literally nothing else to do with their time, than to police people in what they say now and what they said in the past.
What's worse is that they refuse to give you an actual list of what you cannot say. When asked they just reply that "anything that would be offensive." It is completely arbitrary. It can be offensive to them but not to anyone else in the group, or it can be offensive to everyone but not to the problem player (it is rare that the problem player is not offended but I reckon it can happen). It is completely and 100% arbitrary so it is impossible to watch your language. Something that is "wrong" will slip. A wrong word. A wrong emoji. A wrong quotation. There is zero way of knowing how to avoid this.

Threading in this culture is increasingly more dangerous. I wonder how long till we are in a real communist-like era...or maybe we are in that era now. People are already being fired for what they say (bad or not) and for speaking their minds.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @tealishpotato
comment:
Here's a fun anecdote:
Everyone who's played the original Dark Souls knows Gwynevere, and her glorious bonhonagahoogs. According to game director Miyazaki, the giant boobage was the artist's idea, not his, but the aritst was so clearly happy with the design that Miyazaki didn't have the heart to ask him to change it. And so, "Amazing chest ahead" was born.
Creativity thrives in an environment like that.
I feel like if an artist at Ubisoft submitted a design like Gwynevere's today, they'd be promptly sent to HR and fired.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @whogon
comment:
In the middle of my comment, he mentioned the "retarded" thing, for older generations about my age, did ya EVER, TRULY think ü§î...we would make it to a point where the phrase "sticks & stones may break my bones, but words will NEVER hurt me"...got REVERSED? Be HONEST..did u REALLY think it would get THIS soft? We had PLENTY of folks who had the special classes, they may have had mental or physical deficits, but honestly we treated em EXACTLY like we would ANYONE else. These softer generations don't seem to even fully understand, it typically makes people like that, MORE uncomfortable, to have people make a BIG deal about their "deficits", I know I sure as sh** would want folks to treat me the same as everyone else. If anything, the person doin the bullying, would catch a fight, back before guys got expelled for little skirmish level fights.  You'd catch a few days of in-school suspension, but now, if u happen to fight someone & they lose, they can go to their parents, teachers, principal, hell sometimes even Law enforcement, To report a "hate crime". If someone ran their mouth too much, it got "handled". I never realized @ the time, it wasn't far off from a prison-type environment, not even necessarily in a "bad" way, it just shares many of the same things. Funny how I don't see those same soft kids, or slightly older adults w/the minds of children, NEVER see em tryin to stop people from blaspheming. We simply called people who were acting weird of EXTRA soft, "gay", or if we saw somethin that just didn't make sense, we would say "I'm sorry, but that's retarded". I get that younger folks, allow words to destroy their delicate sensibilities, but they're WORDS. It's even protected, as "free speech", although now, of course, even THAT is not for debate (complaining from safe places). People have nearly meaningless lives, so they attach themselves to "causes", attempting to inflate their broken will/ego. Things ran like CLOCKWORK for our generation, if ya stepped outta line, ya paid the price. Now, it's like there's hardly ANY "normal" people, & I would happily say any of this, to basically ANYONE'S face, unless you're like 6ft. 8 & 300 lbs, & built like Ray Lewis or somethin, in that case, I suppose you get a "pass" lol. It's honestly just sad, to see not only gaming, but just culture in general, get deflated into almost nothingness, & the overwhelming majority don't even seem to mind. Other than technology, that gets better EVERY generation, name ONE thing that has TRULY improved in the world? Good luck w/that. Other countries don't even HAVE the OPPORTUNITY for free speech, yet here, sad little cowardly whiners wanna bitch & complain, over WORDS. If words get to you, THAT much, u probably ought 2 just stay FAR away from the Internet, or online gaming, if that's all it takes to "hurt you". Other countries, Sudan, Ethiopia, people don't even know where their next meal is coming from, struggling even w/getting clean water or BASIC medicine to keep themselves/their children alive...yet here's the ENDLESS, pathetic, SAD little cowards who can't handle WORDS . Seriously, u need to grow up, & develop tougher skin, hearing words, does NOT qualify as a "hardship". We get it, u were raised soft, & expect the rest of the world üåé, to be JUST as soft as u are, it's just not. You'll have to overcome, this "deficit". We had NO issues dealing w/kids who had mental or physical deficits, but Y'ALL do. We treated em like we would ANYONE else, someone might make a joke or be a little inappropriate, but we did that w/EVERYONE. Typically, those kids wanna be treated JUST like the rest of us, NOT excluded or havin people point out their problems, or mental/physical issues. As for the games, I've basically boycotted Ubisoft, WAYYY 2 many disappointments. Far Cry 1 & 2 were SO much different, more immersion. Black flag, the new one had like 200 concurrent players, from a self-proclaimed "AAAA" (Quadruple A) studio, even though the entire POINT of that "system", is based on credit ratings, that only go as high as triple-A, defeating even the NOTION of needing a
 "Quadruple 4" rating, it's just something some person within their public relations dept. Came up with, to be able to make it look like their job is necessary. Watchdogs, MASSIVE disappointment. The Division, MASSIVE disappointment, Avatar...Avatarded, Star Wars Outlaws, outside of the hub world that is next to empty, could be ANY other game, only a small amount of time & effort went into the Star Wars "theme". They have a toxic work environment, no innovation or free-thinking, bc larger studios have more mouths to feed. You can pretty much bat that any game that is publicly traded on the stock market, has a TRUE, fiscal responsibility to their shareholders, to make as much as as possible for investors, but NO obligation WHATSOEVER, to "make the best possible game" or "most fun game possible". Now, anything successful gets sequels, remakes, new editions, whatever, bc the bigger corporations just wanna get a return on investment, nothin more. There's a little more to it, but that's basically it, the world üåé as a whole, got soft, dumb, & inexplicably "proud" to be weak-minded fools, or complainers...but ONLY from the safest places, MAYBE 1-2% MIGHT say it to the persons face. The üåé world as a whole, just seems content, to watch everything get WORSE as time goes along, which truly confuses me, as to why they try to push the idea that humanity is "evolving" over time. Technology might be, but good LUCK üëç naming anything else, that gets better each year, rather than worse. Oh well, @ least us older folks had a few good years, I GENUINELY feel bad for most younger folks, who seem to miss ALL the most important parts of life by a COUNTRY MILE...But can't seen to manage hearing words, it's just more than their tiny üíî heart & soul, can bare

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @KennyLi-l3w
comment: There's a saying between trees in a Jungle --- When one giant falls, a hundred saplings will finally have the sunshine to grow. There's also a saying between trees in the Prairie --- If a giant falls, the shade is gone, and that patch of land is forever lost to grass. Are we in the Jungle or in the Prairie? We do not know. Probably somewhere in-between. That is why with Ubisoft, deep-down, we are all very conflicted. We want saplings to grow, but we don't want the biggest shade-provider to die that suddenly, it does NOT sound like a safe thing to do, even for the saplings. As much as each sapling crave for more resource for photosynthesis, everyone knows UV light KILLS, PERIOD. As a gamer, the best scenario is if Ubisoft can somehow steer itself back on a neutral path, no question about it, regardless of your inclinations. But if not... Now it gets interesting. In a "I may die at the end of this but please still hand me the popcorn 'cause I'm gonna enjoy this final show" kind of way.

author: @Haganu
comment:
Rowan Atkinson said it best, back in 2014.

"The best weapon against hateful speech is not repression. It's more speech.
If we want a more robust society, we need more robust dialogue, and that must include the right to insult or to offend.
The freedom to be inoffensive is no freedom at all."

It's crazy how two actors of two different eras acting out someone that says no word at all, really say such profound words that still hold true years down the road.
Society doesn't learn. First Charlie Chaplin and now Rowan Atkinson.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Dawubbz
comment:
If Ubi was actually DEI, the main protagonists would have been a japanese man and woman. There have been 0 of both in the franchise.  There wouldn't have been Chinese architecture being shown off in the game's first gameplay trailer if AC Shadows had actually cared about Japanese history or even the Japanese perspective.  Ubi isn't DEI.  Ubi is cosplaying DEI while selling the same repetitive trash in different skins.  This isn't DEI.  This is rainbow capitalism and tokenism.


Rant below:

A DEI company would have actually consulted with multiple Japanese historians on every single step of the way from world design, to character representation, and even down to the script for the story to ensure that the Japanese perspective would be shown to the fullest.  Sucker Punch did this with Ghost of Tsushima.  Ubisoft is literally more than 100x bigger than Sucker Punch (160 employees vs  19,000), has more resources, AC is one of their few franchises that hasn't been killed somehow, it and can take all the time it wants to do it too. There is no good reason for their products to be worse with that level of manpower.  

 The problem with gaming isn't DEI. This isn't a culture war as much as alt-right nuts like to try to steer people into thinking. The problem with gaming is that greedy companies will cosplay being DEI while still trying to nickel and dime the player at every single opportunity.   Simultaneously, the games these greedy companies put out are all the same minimum viable product possible because the CEOs want the money quickly, so they can get more stock buybacks.  Inflating the value of their own companies, and giving themselves fat bonuses year round after making record profits year over year.  All while laying off their own dedicated workers by the literal hundreds after they're used up and broken by abusive workplace practices and no union representation.  

The problem with Triple A, Ubisoft, and every major company since 2016 isn't companies are being forced to include black and brown people into workplaces when we've constantly been excluded for no reason other than skin color.   The problem is that huge companies are lazy AND greedy.  They're too lazy to pursue true representation or to even say anything that can be construed as different with their products.  Look at Watch Dogs Legion.  That game had an unique mechanic and a punk take on London literally right after Brexit happened.  Punk is literally about going against the political status quo because the flaws in said system, and Ubi thought it was a good idea to sand every political edge or implication off the "play as anyone" mechanic and story mid-development. As a cherry on top, the game came out broken as well.  The reason the game came out like that at all was because Ubisoft was too greedy, it was so hungry for the short term profit, that it sent the game out before it was actually even ready.  Same thing happened with Valhalla as well.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @austinm5630
comment:
On the broader topic of out-of-touch management, I wish someone could explain to me why an entry-level manager makes more money than a line worker.  If a company loses all its managers, stuff will still get done.  It'll be inefficient and sloppy and whatever, but the product will still get made and sold.  If a company loses all its line workers, it's out of business, period.  Ergo, the actual workers have more value to the company than the management does.  So why is management paid better when they're less essential to making money?

The entire concept makes no sense.  And it has never made sense.  This aspect of work isn't new.  But it has never, ever made sense that a low level manager makes more money than the people below him.  If anything, the lowest level of management should make less than the box boy does.  Management shouldn't pay even as much as the workers until you're at least site manager.  Once you're managing the entire store/factory/etc., at least you're doing a noticable amount of work and you provide some value to the company.  But the assistant manager at Wal-mart who does nothing but boss the 5 checkout clerks around and hand them a key every once in a while should not even be earning minimum wage.

author: @fnhatic6694
comment:
The thing is, with Yasuke, Ubisoft could've just done what they've done with *every other game*: A) Fictional protagonist who B) Bumps into historical figures in C) Semi-historically accurate adventures that are sometimes steeped with fables and revisionism. Assassin's Creed, from the very first game, has Desmond asking why the Animus is depicting things that didn't historically happen, and the explanation is that history was altered/lost/covered up, and some stories became myth. 

Yasuke would've been a normal inclusion for that. But we all know that there's probably a scene where the player, playing as Yasuke, has a knee on his back shouting "I CANATU BREEVARU".

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Art-of-War-y6g
comment: For a long time, a key issue for mainstream companies has been the over-monetization of their own IPs, pushing them to the point of self-destruction. This involved producing minimal or repetitive content, speeding up release cycles, and implementing microtransactions. As a result, many industry-leading game developers lost the trust of the gaming community. While customers learn very slowly, they do eventually catch on, and over time, many once-promising IPs collapsed despite their potential to remain profitable assets for the companies. When you pair this issue with the relatively new ideological indoctrination forcing you to take a certain worldview, or get punish when you resist, then the critical mass has been reached.

author: @Marius696969
comment: personally i dont even think having Yasuke in the game was a bad idea, as far as the time period goes its period correct. we have historical documents that he was a retainer of Nobunaga. the problem is their push for him to be a samurai to lift him into a status that he never had. he was a retainer sure, but really he was likely no more than a slave with fewer restrictions than other slaves. the Japanese understood full well the concept of buying a person, they knew that when they bought Yasuke off the Dutch he was their slave. the only difference was the Dutch weren't a warrior culture at the time and the Japanese were so they admired his skill in the battlefield. that doesn't change the fact that he was still likely just a slave. they could have kept Yasuke in the game, made him just a body guard to Nobunaga, maybe gave him a few lines or even a small part in the story with the main assassin, and just left it at that. make him effectively an easter egg for history buffs. if they want a black person as a main character in a game they could easily make an assassins creed take place in somewhere like ethiopia, plenty of religious things going on in that part of africa that they could easily tie into Isu tech like they did with the Vatican in AC 2. its just typical these days that holywood and a lot of "progressive" people just want to place black people everywhere else but in sub saharan africa where they have lived for thousands of years.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @jockpackage1770
comment:
The sad part is, as much as Shadows is marching off to hell um Sony may have lead Suckerpunch's Ghost Of Tsushima sequel down a similar road. Now I doubt that, unless most of the team left, Ghost Of... Fuck some mountain in Hokaido I think, will be nearly as bad as AC Shadows is.
That said, Ghost Of Tsushima won a bunch of awards and was beloved by Japan. Some of the devs were even named embroiders of Tsushima island. You heard right, devs of the original game were given political status in recognition for their respect for the island's history and culture, that they showed in their historical fiction story. Contrast this with how Shadows is being received over there, I don't care how much better Ghost Of... Is, Any comparison to Shadows by making it woke that that will hurt this game and the studio quite a bit. It's likely not even their fault, Sony likely had mandates that they had to follow when this game was being developed.
It's also hilarious to me that they moved the clock so far forward, like over 300 years, to a time that is much more stable in Japan. There was a lot more you could do with post Mongol invasion, warring clans, samurai maybe digging up some of those old iconic Mongol weapons as they stray from the honorable path and you must follow their lead once again for survival. Nope, none of that. This is set in Edo period, likely just to paint the "Europeans bad" angle. Also, without that active war, you can't give the same stakes to the story and thus the character choosing to go down the path of the ghost is much less meaningful of a struggle.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @johnmccall4528
comment:
When I first started playing Ubisoft games waaaaaaay back in the old days before even Assassin's Creed I remember them focusing solely on making good games. Then over time, I started to notice in the intro screens messages about the game being made by a team with various religious faiths and beliefs, and I thought Okay, whatever. then it was a multicultural team with various religious faiths and beliefs, then a multicultural team with various faiths, beliefs, sexual orientations, and gender identities, and I thought to myself 'Who the hell cares about any of this?' Does the actual end user ever give a crap about any of this identity politics crap? I mean sure the increasingly liberal game review mags will lap it up and the corporate shills will love it but what about the whole reason why the industry even exists in the first place? The gamers? Do they give a flying monkey's ass if the people who develop their games have their hands in every sector of identity politics known to man? I sure as heck don't. And I noticed as these messages got longer, and longer the quality of their games started to decrease steadily until now they are nearly unrecognizable from what they once were.

Along with ditching monetization schemes the industry needs to ditch the DEI and ESG initiatives because the actual end users are getting sick of it. The video game industry was MADE into a multi-billion dollar entertainment industry by passionate developers who made high-quality enjoyable products and is being driven into the ground by greedy corporations looking to drain every last dollar from their customers' wallets while paying lip service to ID politics. It's like a vampire that is sucking the life out of this industry and once the gaming industry is well and truly dead they'll just move onto their next victim.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @pumad
comment: I worked at Ubisoft within the PR Department some years ago. The descent from an industry leading and innovative game studio to a soulless woke-driven company is sad to watch. I remember, I talked with devs that were involved with AC and AC2 back then, and they were always so excited when they talked about the future and a possible AC in Japan. They were so fixated on historic accuracy and innovative ways to implement new gameplay mechanic. I remember their discussion about ideas for a Ninja AC character and they were so sure, that it would become a milestone AC-Game in the franchise just because Ninjas and the Hashassins of the orient were so alike and all the possibilities for good storytelling and gameplay mechanics. Well, they are not with Ubisoft anymore and I like to believe they look at their former company today and think: "How the hell can you mess up this golden opportunity and dissappoint all players with that garbage?" Let's face it - Ubisoft is dead inside. Now its just rotting and we all can watch and see it rot away.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Tentacl
comment:
Specifically about the "no beautiful characters allowed", I'm not even that worried about beautiful characters, but I want them replaced by COOL ugly, not "unpopular in high school" ugly.

Using one of my favorite games, BG3, as example: Karlack is one of those cases for me: I'd much prefer her not to be a larger but cute red woman but a monstrouous behemoth disfigured ih hell. This something Ferra/Tor from Mortal Kombat X, or even someone witl one more arm, etc. But BG3 has the opposite issue, the mandatory romances made your whole entourage at least palatable - add to this the mandatory "one of every race" and there is no space for actually COOL companions - so we get no half orc, no dwarf, no actually monstruous war machine Karlack, etc.

Now the opposite effect, using CP2077 expansion, Shadow Liberty: You have a wheelchair bound hacker and noone feels it's silly or artificial inclusivity. Why? Not only the dude is a villain but incredibly ugly and the design is COOL AF.  They also added an asian chick and a black dude as pivotal characters and noone call it DEI. Why? Great writting and performance by Idris Elba Elba.

In the end of the day, using all those corpo buzzwords just make even harder to make a great game, like any other limitation. Thing is, Ubisoft let go talent to reach quotas, and that makes creating good games hard and basically impossible if you add DEI and other safety measures.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Qichar
comment:
I can understand Japanese people being upset about a game exploiting their culture for profit.  Maybe it negatively impacts sales in Japan.  As a Chinese person growing up in the US, I am all too familiar with Western lack of respect and disregard for eastern cultures.

However, I can't get behind this whiny entitlement from gamers.  They are video games.  Planes are not crashing from the sky and killing people like when corporate greed at Boing is rampant.  Please get a sense of perspective.  Nothing epitomizes Western culture more, in my opinion, than your disrespectful attitude of entitlement, as if other people should serve you if you have money and are paying for a product or a service.

I've been playing video games since Pong and Adventure on the Atari 2600.  I've played just about every genre of game, and while I am not myself a game developer, I am a software developer and my wife is in the gaming industry (artist).  So it's not like I have anything against gaming or the industry.  But I don't think game devs OR their studios need to feel badly about getting things wrong.  Gamers can provide feedback, but the game makers don't OWE gamers anything, certainly not the public apology you imply you're asking for.  Either you buy their product and like it, or you don't.  Vote with your wallet.   Most retailers have a policy where you can return games you don't like within a certain time period.  The way gamers go the forums and post whatever the insults they please is the REAL TOXICITY here.  You act as if the people creating these games are not people and should be lynched because they did not properly research their target culture.

If Ubisoft is really tone deaf to gamer complaints they'll got out of business like they deserve to--plain and simple.

comment:
Honestly, Yasuke not being that historically relevant, and with most of the details about his life being pretty contentious and unclear, it makes him the perfect protagonist for a historical fiction game. People didn't have a problem with completely made up characters with absolutely no historical relevance whatsoever, it makes no sense to have a problem with it now. Additionally, portraying him as a Samurai isn't incorrect, because we don't actually know whether he was one. What we do know is that he handled a lot of tasks that were typically done by Samurai, and was strongly favored by Oda Nobunaga, even to the point of being given land.
Aside from that, the games routinely mythologize the historical figures it works with, such as Da Vinci and the Medici family. Same with the borgias or Washington or Lee. The series has always exaggerated the historical figures in its various settings, even from the very beginning of the series.

The rap is a bad choice, but I get what they're going for with it. They're using music to emphasize him being a fish out of water, drawing attention to how alien this environment feels to him. The problem is twofold, for one the music they chose does a terrible job of communicating that, and the second problem is that rap has nothing to do with the culture he would've been from and is extremely anachronistic.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @bomber66a
comment:
the pendulum swinging too far the other way is not good, but neither is using your upbringing to justify the use of words that have become taboo. You banning the person who raised you saying Ret*d is pretty much the same as HR pulling people in for an ! (arguably worse because Ret*d has become offensive). 

It is possible to reflect, research, change and grow. Emotional reaction to criticism is understandable but then acting from that emotional place is not always the best idea. 

Context does matter and I think public figures need to be more aware of their use of language. Just because you don't think it's offensive, doesn't mean that there are those in your audience who do think it is due to their history with the word being used against them. More importantly, those people aren't likely to speak up either as they are - rightly - afraid of then being targeted e.g. you banning the person who bought it up. Instead, they'll just leave your space. 

This stuff isn't black and white, the extreme examples can be ridiculed but there is value in nuance and discussions around language use and how it can include/exclude/hurt/help people.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @t3hp0larbear
comment:
First and foremost, I agree that Ubisoft has a toxic positivity problem based on what I've been seeing and reading. There does need to be some level of friction and conflict/resolution in order to make any sort of quality product.

However, call me crazy but I find it a bit hypocritical that the ideal being presented in the topic of this video is "there needs to be some level of friction and dissent to better ourselves" and then you turn around and tell us about how you insta-banned someone from your stream chat because they called you out in one of the most _mild_ ways I've ever seen as an example of how people are "waiting to be offended." Nothing about this sits right with me.

I'm not going to assert that nobody is like that (I definitely have dealt with people that have victim complexes), but I will assert that many of these folks, including the one you banned, is just going about their business and they hear a word or phrase that feels like they felt a gross, unexpected crunch while chewing on something soft. Instabanning someone for a callout, as sick of it as you might be, sends a message of "I'm right, you're wrong, f--- off." The more graceful way of handling it is to go "Not often at all. My bad, I slipped up" and move on. If that person continues giving you shit for it, then you know they're a bad actor looking to be cause problems and you ban them then.

These higher-ups don't realize they're sitting on the edge of a gaming industry bubble due to bad economies. If things progress as is, there's gonna come a point soon enough where that bubble's gonna pop and even the casual gamers they've been using to buoy their new releases aren't gonna be able to afford the low-quality games they're putting out.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @HigherIdeas
comment:
Simple fact is, it's too late and will be too expensive to address most of those criticisms. So they're going with "Heads down and move forward" - Whatever happens happens... They should have made this game a decade ago, since ninja assassins was only natural for AC. Ninjas should have been like the 3rd installment... They waited too long (because of racism, trust me) and now when they're at the bottom of the barrel and finally do Japan, the society has become too culture-sensitive to accept anything but perfect representation of a culture. 

Think about it this way - If they made the first ACs today, wouldn't they have the exact same backlash about mis-representing whatever Arab nation it was meant to be happening in? People weren't outrage-mining back then. They missed the chance to do Japan without this kind of backlash ages ago... Only themselves to blame on that one. But I do also blame modern offence-mining society for being to obsessed with 1:1 culture representation too.

author: @Ganjalf_the_Green
comment: 16:00 this happens all the time. My microwave engineering professor told me that many Antenna companies in America failed because skilled, older engineers who have the "know how" where pushed out because they rightfully deserves higher pay, so for junior dudes being promoted to senior, but with no one to teach them how to work. This is done in order to save money (junior dudes cost less than an old, senior worker), then these managers can write on their CV that "they enhanced the company's incomes during their period there", but the company is obviously doomed to fail. Antennas and electronics it's an extreme field, of course: you either do an antenna right or wrong, and antennas, especially satellite ones, cost even millions... So I'm not surprised something similar happens in the gaming market, too

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @maxis2k
comment:
When it comes to the half Torii gate (and the entire character of Yasuke), it's not that these people are ignorant.  It's that they're blatantly trying to mock and provoke these reactions.  There's internal statements from many companies about how they seek out and implement activist stuff purposefully.  Both because they want to generate outrage marketing.  But also because they genuinely want to spit in the face of the consumers and exert their dominance.  A rep from Sweet Baby Inc recently came out and admitted this.  But we can look at internal videos from Disney and many other companies going back 10+ years for the same thing.

What's different now is that the DEI money is drying up.  In the past, the DEI money they got front loaded before releasing the game made up for lost sales.  But suddenly this year, the shareholders and hedge funds have stopped giving that money.  So they have these games that have been in the pipeline for 3-5 years and they have to release them with the old model.  Everyone from Disney to Warner Bros to Sony to Ubisoft are scrambling to change course.  But they still have years worth of DEI projects to get through.  And activists to fire.  At least a few like SquareEnix seem to be changing course.  But looks can be deceiving.  They looked like they were changing back in 2016...

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @bflippsytrance
comment: Extreme sensitivity with words is censorship in action. I've met quite some people that think they would be on top of any discussion or argument using a gotcha argument about words, automatically placing themselves on a superior moral highground. It's a nihilistic way of just complicating and sometimes ending communication as people don't feel they can express themselves properly walking on eggshells, willfully misinterpreted and attacked on a word steering away from the argument itself. What point is there gloating about a perceived victory when the communication was lost? Any relationship would fail if the only way of sorting an argument is getting your win, it's extremely childish and shortsighted. One thing is sure, you cannot enforce management like this without minions that make sure it's enforced. I feel sad for the ones that suffer under it, but I don't believe such a workplace culture is easily changed.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @wolfumz
comment:
I can see that Disney really throttled the game's content on Star Wars Outlaws, and they didn't want a game where their main character is shooting down civilian ships.  Developers had to walk a fine line.  Their main character is supposed to be a swashbuckling rogue with the _appearance_ of danger, but in reality, had all the soft edges, clean language, and good morals as Mr. Rogers.  I'm sympathetic, that's no simple task, making that all work.

Even so, I haven't bought a Ubisoft game since 2012, lol.  That was when I started to see how venomous and hostile they are to their own players with always-on DRM, and I decided I'm just not going to buy any Ubisoft games anymore.  I haven't regretted my decision. I don't understand why people are still so into them.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Evyanon
comment:
Not to say you‚Äôre wrong about your opinions on Jubilee, but I think that talking to your ‚Äúenemy‚Äù is the best way to empathize and understand them? I recently got into Jubilee, but it‚Äôs not to get angry and argue with people, I legit learned some stuff from  people on the show I disagree with, or thought I disagreed with? Of course I have specific opinions I‚Äôm not going to change (Like I‚Äôm not going to suddenly think fetus‚Äô are worth more than women‚Äôs health care) but I learned more about trans experiences and opinions that are both pro and anti the military ban, or about how easily certain things have been accessible to them.

And even if DURING the debate itself, when people become more defensive and end up arguing (which I can be like during conversations like this) a lot of the time afterwards I will reflect on what they said and do some more research. 

I‚Äôve only watched ones up to a year ago, but I personally think I‚Äôm getting a lot of benefit, especially when I live in a media bubble because of how the internet works, it‚Äôs legitimately hard for me to find voices I disagree with to hear them that aren‚Äôt the top voices (like I can find Alex jones and Ben Shapiro, but I want to hear from smaller people who don‚Äôt have the same talking points every time)

But I do agree with you, I can‚Äôt bring myself to click on the Palestinian one, because I can‚Äôt imagine what it would be like to sit in that room with people on the opposite side when the body count is so high.

author: @rrgale55
comment:
This was a great video. Well done, OP.

I would like to add that I think games should have customizable characters, including gender and pronouns. I'm saying this because how a person wants to represent themselves doesn't affect anybody else's game.

Where I draw the line, is misrepresenting people in history. Yasuke was not a Samari. Sure, he can be a fictional character in a fictional game, but this is Japan. The IP for Assassin's Creed is playing as a character from their respective culture (Origins: Egyptian, Valhalla: Viking, Odyssey: Greek etc).

Feudal Japan should be a Japanese person. It just makes sense!!
