I get why people don't wanna use the "hard R-word" anymore, but i think even the most stupid people today (and there are a lot), understand that NOONE uses it in the original context anymore. Like many other english words that over time started to mean something entirely different.
"I'm not quite up to dick today."
You wouldn't say that, would you? Well, in victorian times that seems to have been a pretty normal phrase for saying you didn't feel too well. Just one example of many such words. (Google this one, you'll find more.)

honestly the anecdote of the R word struck a chord with me. for me growing up its been a common insult like idiot or stupid. but now its seen as a horrific slur, however people with neurological disorders aren't called that anymore and the word isn't used in that context anymore. so realistically it doesn't refer to them anymore.

comment: I have absolutely no problem - whatsoever - with "DEI" - how could anyone? But I won't buy anything from Ubisoft, ever, because their suggestion to get used to never owning games is something I was happy to take only too literally. Careful what you wish for, 'big tech', 'tech bro' CEOs. Quadruple A for *sshole I'd say. These days I'm indie only, DRM free as much as possible, but sure I love some DEI. DEI is also-known-as 'the world' and people aggressively objecting to DEI should get out of their basements and preferably their home towns as much as they dare. That said, the protagonists in AC Odyssey seemed decidedly 'Greek' and if we've waited decades for AC Japan then i'd prefer the lead character to have most of the hallmarks of a largely Japanese heritage. With Star Wars i couldn't give a rats *ass. Any gender, any race is fine with me - its intergalactic - and yes, young girls need to grow up believing a space outlaw could be a woman and not just another waitress. You've got to be a sad individual to be hurt about that.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @TheIntelligentVehicle
comment: Sometimes entire industries have to hit rock bottom before they change. I'd speculate that due to longer lead times, the gaming industry will be a couple years behind industries like advertising and Hollywood in the inevitable pivot. I'd claim Hollywood is already turning the ship. Twisters without any self-righteous speech about climate change. Deadpool & Wolverine and not Deadpool, Wolverine, Their Toxic Masculinity, and Mary Sue. In fact, I think I heard something about a BS toxic masculinity-themed scene being cut from that film before it was released. Sign of the times. The blockbuster hits so far in 2024 show you can push society forward in positive directions without playing up disgusting (imo) politics. Inside Out 2 was at the top of the chart last I checked, and while I haven't seen it, the idea that you can deal sensitively with the human condition does not require pushing an idea of the human condition that is unrecognizable to most actual human beings. I think most people would argue that it's impossible to deal with the human condition if you end up distorting it, in fact. I'm pretty confident the gaming industry is going to pivot, too. Will Ubisoft survive until they are able to do the same? I hope so, but no studio or IP is irreplaceable.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @emrickazor2610
comment:
I'll give Ubisoft this - I should have done my research. I was not aware of Yasuke's existence. And considering Ubisoft's choices lately, I had chocked it up to "We put a black main character in and disregarded historic accuracy, but if you're offended by this, you're clearly racist.". Though it STILL feels like their reasoning, just with a different fuel.

I feel like Ubisoft is just making bold choices to be controversial, but in such a way where you look like the bad guy for being annoyed by it.

I have NO issue with black characters in games. I think diversity in gaming is part of what makes it good. If every character in a game was a white guy with blond hair, it'd be bland. But modern game devs need to also learn that every character being a mixed race they/them is ALSO bland. I'd also like to say - as a member of the LGBTQ community - I feel insulted MORE by the shoehorned inclusion JUST to sell a game. A character cannot be a good character on the grounds that they're gay. They have to actually have a reason to be good. IDGAF who they're interested in, that doesn't effect their skills, like guys, like girls, be asexual, idgaf you do you, but you have to have substance. Unless these things play into their character in a major way - maybe your MC is gay, but is from a town who's laws/traditions shame and exile gay people. A strong narrative like that can make you feel your character's motive. Rather than "This is MC, he is gay, he likes men. He likes me. That is all. He likes men. Oh I guess she goes on adventures too.".

Replace "gay" with anything, your MC could be white, black, hispanic, straight, gay, bi, ace, so on. As long as they aren't banking on their skin color or their sexual orientation as their only redeeming feature. This is the BIGGEST issue plaguing modern gaming, I think.

Games were so much more inclusive back when they weren't trying to be. Metroid is an amazing example of this. Metroid 1's manual teases that Samus is a man. Tells you that she's a guy the entire time. You're not really caring, I don't think, it's a cool game. Then you beat the game and find out that this badass you've been playing the entire time is a woman. Samus EARNED her place as a strong female protag. Meanwhile you can guarantee that any game with a female protag NOW is just gonna put it in your face that she's strong, and never give you  reason to believe it.

I want representation and inclusion in gaming, I genuinely do. But I don't like what we're stuck with right now. I shouldn't like a character because I'm gonna be seen as racist/sexist/homophobic for disliking them. I should like a character because I like them.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @canadianoperator
comment:
This doesn‚Äôt surprise me. Ubisoft has been coming off the rails for a long time now. 

I used to respect them and be proud that they had a studio in my backyard. I used to enjoy their games for the gameplay and spend hundreds of hours in worlds they created. 

Today‚Äôs Ubisoft is only a shell of its former self. 

From my personal experience I have found blatant misrepresentation of game mechanics and features, greedy micro transactions which assist you in getting past artificially inflated grindy game sections, a complete lack of attention when it comes to storytelling, character development and player experience, and dismissive behaviour towards customers and their biggest fans. 

It‚Äôs so unfortunate to see a studio that once made incredible games like Splinter Cell or Ghost Recon completely fall apart and become another EA or Activision. 

I played the technical test and beta for breakpoint and it was an absolute mess. There was barely any audio, animations and textures were completely missing, and it looked like a PS2 game. But the cash shop worked flawlessly. 

I bought Watch Dogs Legion with the promise of awesome features like being able to play as anyone, and then was shocked to discover bugs and technical issues that could have been squashed before release, game ending crashes, terrible controls, awful voice overs and basically the same handful of perks for every character. I asked for a refund after 30 minutes of play and was denied because I ‚Äúlaunched the game‚Äù. I had to get help from PayPal to get my money back for a broken mess of broken promises. 

It‚Äôs fair to say I will not be buying a Ubisoft game ever again. This company has lost my fandom, lost my interest, lost my trust and lost my loyalty. I am beyond disappointed that they refuse to see this and take efforts to coerce people into thinking differently while doing nothing about the reason people think this way about them. 

It‚Äôs a shame.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Hyziant
comment:
Sorry but I heavily disagree with the interviewee in how they frame the issue surrounding the effects of the MeToo movement. The execs that left because of that movement would have left because either

1. They knew they engaged in sexual harassment or assault and needed to leave before they got caught
2. They were caught doing sexual harassment and assault

The interviewee wants to frame this as a bad thing by implying ‚Äúfixing sexual harassment/assault issues = boring games‚Äù. However, there is no causal link between the two. It is completely possible and normal to have a healthy workplace and still make good games. Nothing about holding people accountable for sexual harassment or assault would inherently affect game direction, unless the game direction was somehow literally moving towards sexual harassment and assault. I think it is extremely disingenuous for the interviewee to imply that fixing workplace culture makes bad games, and it‚Äôs honestly a huge red flag imo to distrust this person‚Äôs framing of the situation.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @TheRedstonian
comment:
Good video. Something I wanted to mention (I'm not sure if you still read these comments) is that, during Warframe's Whispers in the Walls quest, the entire thing is woven through the narrative of the relationship between Loid and Albrecht, and the only people I can find whinging about it in the comments are people that are so cartoonish about it that I can only assume they're trolls. Even watching you play it, at no point did it bother you, or at least you didn't show it.

The reason is because the game, and the quest, are really fuckin' good. Warframe doesn't have to put in a queer relationship to hide behind inclusivity brownie points, they did it because it made sense!! It fits in the narrative of the Entrati, the social dynamics and situations of the Orokin, the roles Albrecht and Loid had in their work. It was thought out and well done and passionately crafted to tell a story with good payoff.

I mean, shit, even years ago Warframe had a quest about an autistic kid that got rejected by the Tenno of the Zariman, **because** of his autism. And at no point did it feel like it was preaching a message - it was part of the story, and it mattered.

Warframe has never been a "boy's club", Warframe has never had to chase sex pests out of their executive suite. You know what, we can even toss in that Warframe is Woke as shit, due to their support of LGBT charities and vocal support of their queer staff.

The game is a fucking blast, so nobody cares about the woke. Hope you can use this as a talking point in a later video to explain the intellectual dishonesty on the topic.

19:53 Yes indeed, but you know what ? I did the most logical thing to do, something that needs to believe in life and bet on yourself. You just leave a company like that and rebound somewhere else.

comment: You had me with the Slayer shirt. Unfortunately we live in a crazy world. Do you remember when the customer was always right. Those days are gone. Just like Radio, TV, and the Internet this form of entertainment has been hijacked by hypocritical ideologues.  Isn‚Äôt the focus of a business on making money. A clean slate to program. So it‚Äôs happening and it‚Äôs not going to stop. Not until the next trend hits. How much profits have these companies made? That they can blatantly slap its consumers in the face. And say screw you buy it. Look 2010 was a boom year in video games. Mass effect 2 um yummy. Anyway but at that point you have to realize games were made by gamers for gamers. White males for white males??? I‚Äôm not going there. I‚Äôm not saying that. I am saying the developers were growing with the tech in real time. So in 2007-2014 you had basically master degree or doctor status working on games. A maturity of growing with the process. It truly was a golden age of gaming. Gaming had arrived and delivered mature narrative‚Äôs that their aging fan base craved. Have you ever seen the level of maturity of one of these woke warriors? These woman child developers have no clue what the masses want. And they no longer care. What can I say social engineering at its finest. Expect an even more emotionally and physically weaker generation. All brought to you by angry women. Back in 2007 games in a lot of ways were chasing Hollywood. Not anymore. Gaming is a big business now. Which is another problem all together. But look at whose making these modern video games. And look at their world view. Vote with your wallet. Games only come down in price. So play your back log. Wait‚Äôem out the kids will make up the difference. It‚Äôs like the cable company everyday a gamer puts down his controller for one reason or another. And some dumb kid gets his first console as a present. And so on and so on. title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @snoookie456
comment:
The ad men that have infested video games the same way they made their way through all of entertainment are essentially the type of people who genuinely believe that there is "no such thing as bad publicity". This phrase has been unironically repeated so often while I've been alive that I don't even remember if I've ever seen "good publicity". 

To me "publicity" is synonymous with bad. It's all just bad. The best things right now are things with NO publicity. This is why indie games are killing it right now. Because they're made by gamers for gamers with NO publicity. As soon as you get a hint of publicity, all of it is ruined by greedy corporations who have no clue what they're working on and who their audience is. 

Remember Rockstar? Up until RDR 2 (imo the best game I've ever played), their games came out with little to no publicity. Rockstar would publish a screenshot, or a 20 second teaser, or even just the Rockstar logo in the color scheme of the new release. RDR 2 had like an Arthur Morgan teaser... 20 seconds... they were too busy making the actual games to think of any commercials. Now studios are too busy making commercials, they forget about the actual game...

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @carlosmoore2080
comment:
Look I'm going to be completely honest with all of you . I don't agree with everything development teams do but the fake gaming justice warriors BS needs to stop these games are art created by someone else's imagination not meant to please all but those who see the beauty in their work. Y'all have brought this feminine energy into gaming with topics like historical accuracy and many other topics that are irrelevant being as though these games are figments of someones imagination. Is space marines2  , wukong , or final fantasy historically accurate. No they are imaginary stories. Y'all always find something to gripe about . Though you are free to feel what you feel that's cool but the toxic stuff y'all are doing is out of hand. Using your platforms to influence gamers to cancel games just because y'all don't like them is selfish and effects other gamers that don't have the same views. Some of us who have been gaming far beyond the time some of you were even born welcome a new type of experience and are more concerned with real life than gaming politics and view gaming as a pass time, a hobby , an escape. Y'all are ruining it completely. There is a flip side to every coin. The gaming community with these bs politics have gotten developers so nervous to work on new IPs that everyone is just working on remakes and remasters dating back to Atari . 
Most of the games topping this year off are proof of my point and next year will be the same. If you want to play a game you played 10 years ago go back to your old console and play it or play it on your computer. I personally don't want to live in what feels like a simulation or ground hogs day where it's the same thing over and over . If you do that's cool but do it at your own expense in your own home stop trying to effect everyone else with your own wants . Like every game should be made for you like $70 bought you shares in the companies. Play it or don't but stop trying to promote other people not playing these games. Influencers hate on a game still but it and make money off of their viewers watching them partake in the experience. If they felt so strongly they wouldn't even do a walkthrough or review of a game they claim to find repulsive yet all of them do . I find that to be quite hypocritical. How y'all going to influence others not to buy something but yet y'all buy it after the fact . Just for views and to try and find ways to cripple sales even more. Y'all did that with days gone ruined chances for a sequel to come out just like many other Great games not because they were bad but just because they aren't to your specific liking . I'm not trying to be mean but I hope the development companies go back to the ways of old and stop allowing y'all any access to any information pertaining to future releases other than a trailer , a release date trailer, a little game play and a demo and start copyright striking y'all for influencing the market , videos based on speculation, and opinions from people who actually have poor taste in the first place . I hope gaming gets super expensive so alot of the people encouraging this destructive behavior will leave and gaming can be gaming again instead of these nonsensical hive mind conversations from people that think because they built a PC they have a masters in game development and they don't know nothing other than what everyone sees online but not the least bit of trade school or college education nor hands on experience on the topic .  Why must y'all gossip, cry and complain about everything. In the 70s ,80s, and 90s those were categorized as feminine traits men either participated or didn't and kept going not trying to effect others but just participating in what suited them . Y'all different y'all try to change everything dispute other people to fit your own selfish wants rather than realizing that everything is not for you and let others enjoy what they like free from bland or any others critique or opinions. Stop trying to dictate what's available in the market that's exactly what the outcome of this crap is but some of u are to unwise to realize the outcome will not work in your favor and ruin millions of others  experience in the process all out of selfishness and greed over something you didn't create, own the rights to ,or no contribution to the making of in any aspect. Privilege in rare form. Stop ruining gaming we getting remastered 8bit Halloween games because of y'all old arcade games because of y'all instead of more innovation like stellar blade and wukong. Most developers are scared to try because of y'all whining.

author: @FrenchyMcToast
comment: Here's how I know that the assertion that the cultural complaints are westerners pretending to be Japanese:  I'm an enormous weeb, and have been for more than 20 years.  I know more about Japan than any average westerner _could._  I'm not professing any kind of expertise here, I'm merely setting the scale when I say that I have never heard of the things that are being brought up.  I had no idea about the half tori, or the statue, or the heraldry.  These are the kinds of things you would only know if you were a native or if you were a historian.  The fact that Ubisoft has supposedly hired experts and have caught none of this shows their lack of care.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @mrpostaldude8289
comment: Just subscribed. I like how neutral and objective you approach this topic and other sensitive ones in the past, without constantly firing up the rage train. The problem for Ubisoft might indeed be the aftermath of this harassment affair couple years back. If you had such a toxic environment before, you hire people who literally breath a different kind of spirit. It's very likely that they also found their way into development. And if everything is falling under the terms diversity, safe spaces and awareness, it at some point has to overcome the barrier into the actual work. The ambiguity here is that games are usually mimicking a hostile, but fully fictional environment on purpose to create thrill, keep you occupied and let you escape reality. Removing or watering this down simply neutralizes the purpose of the game and the reason why you bought it. And that's why not only the Ubisoft games do not sell anymore since a couple of years, but also the ones from other big publishers because they sacrifice the product over politics.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Necrilem
comment:
As someone with professional education in design, I cannot consider these CEOs, devs, chair men and whatever nobodies that insult us gamers/customers/consumers (Like just recently Sawn Layden on Ghost of Yotei for example) and melt down all the time as creatives nor professionals. Rather than actually listening to the information given through responses/feedback/outcry etc., be it sometimes more erratic and aggressive, they completely deflect everything and stubbornly refuse to acknowledge any responsibility or issues.

One of the fundamental truths of design is that other perspectives are crucial to high quality and improvement. As a creative, you should CHERISH feedback/criticism. Feedback and other people's perspectives are what allows you to evolve, to thrive. It is the very essence of what allows creative spaces and industries to grow and evolve.

These people are doing the exact opposite. They are incompetent and ignorant. They continuously deploy logical fallacies or spew nonsense that has 0 logical cohesion, rather than reflecting and improving. They limit creative choices and modify every single bit necessary to fit their modern ideology. They are causing creative stagnation and ever more often creative decline. That is not how mature people act.

These people are an embarrassment.

DEI Ideology and snowflake-ism or whatever umbrella term you want to use compromises narrative integrity, authenticity, cohesion and overall quality and innovation of game design. It is something that comes after and isn't part of anything organically. It is coming up with a creative vision, a narrative and overall game features and then modifying them to fit this modern ideology.
It is not creative freedom as long as it's legal anymore. It is creative enslavement and restriction to conform to ideological acceptance. It is censorship to a very deep and disgusting degree.

The video games these company's make aren't creative endeavours anymore, they are commercial products intended to drive short-term profit and feed into their modern ideology conforming success metrics with complete neglect to any creative aspect of it or whether it is good or not.

As someone who has been playing games and gaming since 1987,  Ubisoft may have a lot of issues, but Star Wars outlaws got way more crap than it deserved  it wasn‚Äôt perfect, but it was a decent game and a pretty good time.  And I‚Äôm sorry you may not agree but meta critics reviewers scores were accurate. It‚Äôs a 7-7.5/10. A decent game but certainly not perfect. I played it and finished it and that‚Äôs an accurate assessment. If you got it for 1799 like I did on Ubisoft plus (which I canceled after the one month) it was even better. That said I‚Äôm hopeful they might be doing some changing.  And they need to take bigger swings and not be so safe. 
Also quoting anything from asmon is idiotic because all that guy does is complain about everything in nearly every video. He‚Äôs complained about the new dragonage despite never playing it despite the Youtubers, who have saying that it‚Äôs shaping up to possibly be a pretty good game. Nothing he says, has any validity to me anymore because all I hear him do is complain about things without ever touching them. You can say what you think it looks like, but you can‚Äôt flat out say a game sucks  for sure without ever playing it. I don‚Äôt care what anyone says. I don‚Äôt agree with that.

author: @necasperaterent29386
comment:
I used to work in the space: The truth is that ever since metoo, a lot of companies, even entire governments, have completely lost the plot. They willingly handed the reigns over to lunatics, who screamed very loudly and assertively, and who kept waving their diplomas in "comparative trans-studies" or whatever and claimed to have all the answers. These are completely idiology-driven people, with a VERY cult-like mentality, who live (in their minds) in a world where everything is sunshine, rainbows, pride flags and constant validation of the most insane positions or for accomplishing the most basic tasks as a functioning human, while they are willing to send anybody to forced re-education camps (or worse) that they deem to be in the way of that. Their mindset is pitifully soft/weak AND murderously draconian/sadistic at the same time. These people positively revel at the prospect of having the power to punish and torture others, and to force others to listen to their crap. 

Worst of all is that this cult-like way of thinking has become so pervasive to us as a society, all kinds of media, and high-level business especially, that I fear that there is no coming back before a complete collapse. We stand on the brink of economic disaster because this mentality puts ideology over what is fiscally responsible or good practice. Look at the elections: The amount of times you hear people wanting to vote democrat because "black woman president *YAAAAS!!!* " without even knowing or understanding an iota of what said candidate plans to do is STAGGERING to me. It's the same everywhere else. Fucking frightening, really.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Retro_simone
comment: Gamedev here ; It's like that everywhere nowadays.  Even studios that used to be all about the passion have become so big corporations. I had 1 lead before that was supervising my work - that used to be the one mentoring me, that build the studio. Within the last year before I left, I had 1 lead, 1 director, 1 senior director, and most of them are people who joined the company within the past year or past few months, being promoted up to 4 times in a year, while I have been there 7 years. My promotion was denied over and over because of "attitude" problem -- attitude that goes against the company view and ended me at HR more than once (that attitude problem was me complaining the game we are working on is not good enough and we should do more but  the answer I got was "Meh, good enough"). Those new hires have no experience at all , and they aren't gamers, they come in and want to change everything we've been working on for the past year or so, and are so ego driven. It's sad. Luckily, I could retire. Look a bit around, lot of people who've been with big studios are leaving, so many veterans are just starting their own companies or retiring, this is a reason for that. By the end I was working 17-18h a day, 7/7. While other were promoted and cut everything down at 4pm every day. Barely doing anything, always that mentality "It's good enough, nobody cares." I didn't think it was good enough. I couldn't be associated with that kind of work, so I left.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @wolfchadaverageusenjoyerza8288
comment: Even if I couldn't care less about japanese culture and their feelings about the game (or whatever that is), what I really care about is the AC IP, as well as the other Ubisoft IPs. At the end of the day, gameplay is king, and if they start making good games again, they will be successful no matter what, let's be real. Therefore, in the long term I think this might be a necesary lesson for Ubisoft to be learned, if we want to get rid of stuff like microtransactions, unpolished games, live service, free-to-play games, NFTs and season passes. Maybe after all, this whole "cultural war drama" non-sense might actually bring positive changes to Ubisoft. We are already seeing them trying to polish the game, add more side quests, offer the first expansion for free and getting rid of the season pass. I hope it comes to the point where they drop the live service formula and start to do complete and high quality single player games again as they used to. Even if I often criticize Ubisoft, that's because I love their IPs; I want them to improve, I don't want Ubisoft to fail, but just to do good games again.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @SalvationCode
comment:
The vast majority of AC fans have zero issues with Yasuke. Astroturfed grifter rhetoric doesn't change the fact that Ubisoft has taken massive liberties with their historical figures since the dawn of AC. 

This might come as a shock, but Leonardo Da Vinci didn't actually build Bond gadgets for Ezio in real world history. Nor did he build fully functioning war machines (flying machines with explosive projectiles, manned tanks, war boats). 

This is called historical FICTION. That's why we can have Yasuke as a protagonist in Shadows. Ubisoft is doing what they've always done; taking characters we have little overall info on, and integrating them into AC lore. It doesn't matter if him being a samurai is debated or not. AC is not 100% historically accurate. It never has been. Anyone claiming otherwise is a tourist.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @v2micca
comment: I'm reminded of a video that Thor did over on his channel.  There was a section of his game that a user complained about, claiming that it was simply there to pad out the length of the game to  keep gamers from demanding a steam refund.  Thor points out how absurd the argument behind the complaint is as he notes that the games entire run time, even with the section in question was still fairly short and would allow players more than enough time to process a steam refund.  But he also noted, that even though the player was making a demonstrably incorrect assumption in his complaint, there was validity to the complaint in that the section of the game in question wasn't good, didn't add to the overall experience and generally wasn't fun.  So, he removed that section o the game, replaced it with something else, and made the game better.  I think AAA devs have completely lost the ability to actually analyze criticism and distill down the valid issues that their costumers are trying to convey.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @GoddofStuff
comment:
Long goes the time where games were developed by people who wanted to make good games.

In these day and age, and particularly most big companies who have any sort of software development, regardless of it being games, products, whatever, this is the new reality now - This companies hire developers, they hire managers, and thus the problem begins, because while the company is growing, they only look at results, and unfortunately DEI happened, and everyone thought diversity would fix everything and make them gain millions and now, we're seeing the results of these twisted ways of working. Regarding managers, most of them is not even qualified for the job, which generates situations where even if you provide feedback for them that you don't believe the product is going the right way, they don't listen, whether it be because of their ego or because they're afraid of providing feedback for the upper layer. Regarding DEI, you got companies that hire people based on diversity quotas, which makes teams worse because most of the times they're just null, or you get people pushing agendas that have nothing to do with making something good. Allied to this, as you go up the ladder, you have people who care less and less  because by the end of the year they get their massive bonuses and if things go wrong they're probably set or will just move on as if nothing happened.

The reality is that today, you're forced to work in a fast paced environment where you're exploited to the bone, and where it's preferable to do things fast and shady, than to make things the correct way at first. Teams are mostly lead by people who lack the correct vision, and that think that what they design and they're ideas are final and are the best thing in the world, and when they receive feedback that things are not like that, they get surprised and blame the bottom layer. I know you like video games, so you can verify this for instance with WoW and D4, where you clearly see that player feedback doesn't match with the final products being delivered, and yet you had interviews from Ian for instance in shadowlands, where he said that they know how to design things and their vision was final, and that expansion was a debacle (the famous pull the cord). Next expansion he explained that most of the expansions are already in a pre development state, and that's why things take time to change, but still, you see that even today WoW and D4, even though they improved a few things, still keep insisting in the most of the stupid, petty, ignorant approaches to the game - I can think of why on earth on WoW raids you have to clear so much trash, and when you die you have to run like hell to get to the boss you died at... This are all little things, but if you export this to everything else, you can see how a company works, how leadership behaves, and why we get the products we get.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @knexfan100
comment:
17:39 You didn't do your research and completely misrepresented the data and the dates of the 2 articles....that Tom Henderson piece dropped the day before the black ops 6 "beta" (it's a demo, let's be real) claiming the playerbase is dead and the game would be canceled in season 3 with zero sources other than a "trust me bro" and a spotty history where he wrote articles that were meatriding battlefield 2042..... Dude gets paid to write articles that are practically commercials/hit-pieces pretty often...


That article you talked about before isn't Ubisoft, that was Mark Rubin explaining the patch notes for the freshly-announced season 2 update.... the same update that provided us a roadmap to season 4 and the same week we got leaks for season 6...... invalidating the Tom Henderson article as a paid article (Activision is well-known for paying writers to write hit pieces on other competing games before release).

You can prove the game isn't dead by just playing it.... Last night on XDefiant doing my camo grind my matchmaking on a custom playlist got me into a game within 20 seconds.

18:55 You're being dishonest again... let's leave cod alone for now: COUNTERSTRIKE 2 DROPPED WITH TRASH NETCODE. COD IS INFAMOUS FOR PACKETLOSS.

I do have my issues with XD (Mark Rubin going to Ubisoft in the first place with the project, ugly models, Ubisoft forcing them to drop the game early, Ubisoft forcing them to use the Snowdrop engine instead of something normal like Unreal, listening to the idiots on twitter and nerfing the snipers with insane flinch while not at all addressing the broken aim assist abuse at the top levels in ranked), but you can't pretend XD's netcode issues are unique and another Ubisoft failure. Especially with the developers actively talking to players in discord/twitter and immediately applying said feedback to patches within a few days.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @JoeyDND
comment:
Hey!, gay guy here, diversity in media is brilliant when it is done correctly. Create new characters that just happen to be part of *minority or racial group* and make them fantastic. Do not change an established lore or real world history to satisfy some bull quota.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @ericbright1742
comment:
I'm reminded of PirateSoftware/Thor's shorts on how even "bad feedback" can lead to good results. 

One player commented on how Thor added in a "blind maze" section to his game, and they accused him of padding the game so the players couldn't issue a refund.

Obviously this was stupid and nonsensical. The blind maze took anywhere between 2 to 4 minutes to complete if you were thinking about it. 

However, the underlying message of the comment held a kernel of truth: The blind maze sucked, and was not fun. So he took it out, and the game was better for it.

Game Reviews Should Go:

- Pre-Order the game ASAP (Wukong, Balders Gate, AstroBot)
- Buy it Day One (Hi-Fi Rush, Hell Divers)

- Wait till it's free via EPIC/Amazon (Sable,  Blair Witch, Wild West, Suicide Squad, Saints Row)
- Wait till the game is cracked/pirated, make sure dev+pub don't get $$$

Though My boss and intern buddy were barely ever talking to me, i had to ask many times to get feedback on my work. 2 months in a girl came in our team also doing an intership. My boss was talking and helping her everyday. 2 months after, she had not solve one ticket, she had abandonned her first task and working on a second one. At the end of my intership I got told there was no position and was not hired. 

A month later she got hired. I'm not really sure how it happened but it gave me the impression i was never given a fair chance. Maybe she went throught a special diversity program or got lucky... 

Now i work in a company that values my skills. I'm glad it didnt work out üòÇ

@LegendaryDrops
Ubislops also use the Buddha (Nara Daibutsu) statue in their game,
THAT *NO ONE gets permission to use, EVER.*
You Need to have japan and culture ministers permission to use that statue commercially (because it's a Japan national treasure)
But most of the time they give only permission for educational purposes and they need to make it culturally and historical appropriate. 

*quick notes*
Before you say anything like "but there's been a lot of buddha statue in video game especially the current one in Black myth wukong?" 
There are several different buddhas and each country has their own laws on using religious artifacts in media.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @TheMisterGuy
comment: The problem with a "boys' club" like Ubisoft trying to be "diverse" is that you get the worst of both. You still have the stifling environment of the boys' club, so you didn't gain the main benefit of diversity. But you lost the authenticity of making the dudebro content that was near and dear to your heart. You end up with a "fellow kids" take on diversity that the dudebros in your audience hate, and the people who want diversity instantly recognize as inauthentic corpo pandering.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @ThulrVOdinsson
comment: This is, hands down, the most insightful, constructive, and interesting video I've seen on the issues in modern "AAA" (or should I say 'AAAA'?) gaming. You give me hope, in that it seems we are reaching critical mass, and the rot is eating this corporations from within. I imagine the true talent will end up in the indie sphere, and new, smaller, impassioned companies will rise up to fill the holes as the mighty ones of old atrophy into a slow death. I, for one, have completely lost interest in these mega-productions, because I've been disappointed by mediocrity at best, and pure garbage at worst. The days of AAA games resting on the laurels of previous successes are over.

author: @ahmedanubis
comment:
As an Egyptian,

I was amazed by AC Origins not just for the story and how amazing that game was and its dlcs. 
But its portrayal of Egyptians, phenotypically they looked Egyptian the protagonists and npc were not whitewashed or blackwashed as we see a lot in Western media, the lifestyle of the farmers shown in their side missions and npc scripts is accurate to the history and the Egyptian character as the farmer is the best representation of Egypt for 80% of Egyptians were farmers up until the industrial revolution, the class clashes between Egyptians and the Greeks and Romans perfectly captured the Egyptian spirit, they even portrayed the sarcasm in the face of hardship and oppression which is a common trait in Egyptian culture. Their portrayal of ancient Egypt and the Egyptian character was what we all want, Authentic.

Back then there were ACTUAL racist posts about Bayek's voice actor being black and they were all bs imo as Bayek is an Egyptian character, who cares what his voice actor looks like and Abubakr exceeded all expectations in his performance anyways, back then UBI was right to ignore these people, but ever since Odyssey the excessive DEI nonsense is enough reason for people to boycott Ubisoft like they've done.

I miss AC Origins Ubi, That is the Ubisoft I want, the Ubisoft that actually cares about their games' story, world, gameplay, and authenticity!

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @ChimpBrained
comment:
"They dont know how to differentiate bad from good criticism" Yup. Most likely they dont know how to dissect criticism at all, which is a skill any well adjusted person has. 

What is the criticism?
Is it just insults?
What are their points?
Do those points have a basis in reality?
Can those points be acknowledged in a meaningful way that satisfies both criticizer and the one being criticized?
Do those changes have further impact on other areas related to it?
How can I minimize that impact?


Criticism is annoying. Nobody likes being told theyre wrong or should "fix" something, but that is life. You will be wrong at many points, and a mature person will roll with those punches and grow. An even more mature person will look for those criticisms in their life before anyone else can. Essentially being your own critic. Similar to a moral compass, but instead of being something you (Hopefully) inherently have, its a skill you have to work to develop. We can see the results of not developing that skill on display here, and Im sure we have all met someone before who has also not developed it. Annoying, self centered, brats.

The central question is: Will any amount of polishing or more time in the oven make AC Shadows a better game than Monster Hunter Wilds? Likely no. So why would any casual gamer pick up their game over the others releasing within 2 weeks of its release?

author: @Martial-Mat
comment:
The game looks superb. I couldn't give the slightest crap about the precise importance of a black man in the shogun's army. I don't give the slightest crap about the historical accuracy of a building that has Chinese influence rather than Japanese.
I'm incredibly mildly concerned that Ubi stole the flag of some inconsequential Japanese re-enactment group.
I'm ever so slightly more concerned that an action figure that is not even IN the game looks like a gate that was left standing after the destruction of a city that was levelled for attacking a nation it was not even at war with.
All of this pathetic outrage about historical accuracy from people who never THOUGHT about history until this bandwagon started does nothing but make me want to buy it to spite them.

What I DO care about, is the fact Abusisoft's CEO Yves Guillemot, is a sex abuse apologist who ran interference for a senior manager at his company, allowing the man to remain after he harrasseda female staffer to such a degree that she commit suicide.
THAT'S why I'll never buy a full price Abusisoft game as long as he heads the company.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Yzzlthtz
comment:
There‚Äôs disingenuous behavior on all sides here. Yes, there‚Äôs toxic gamers. Yes, there‚Äôs a push for diversity. But if gameplay is king, real gamers should be waiting to play the actual game before passing judgment. Further, Japanese community asking for better Japanese representation IS further wokeness. Diversity CAN be done well - gender fluidity in Elden Ring, for example, or Baldur‚Äôs Gate.
I dislike Ubisoft games for gameplay reasons. I think we, as gamers, should be completely open to experiments in representation. We should be both healthfully discerning and warmly welcoming of anyone who wants to work in this space in the name of welcoming others. We WANT more diverse gaming communities. We WANT ESPECIALLY more gamers, because that means more people to play with and more money for production. We need to end toxic positivity, but there are healthy ways to do ‚Äúwoke.‚Äù More, there are times when it doesn‚Äôt work, but the gameplay is still worthy. Gamers have this tendency to angrily gatekeep, and a I would love to see that change even as we encourage developers to focus on the quality and presentation of gameplay over all other considerations.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @mattinakki8253
comment: I used to dabble with modeling and animation in 3D Studio MAX back in the day. Even considered "This might be fun as a job.". Good thing I didn't follow with that thought. I always wonder how people end up signing up bad contracts as an employee with a gaming company and then going with all kinds of crap for years. Why? You gotta have more self-respect. And if it's not listed in your contract, then you should be allowed to call out bullshit. If not, gather up and sue them. But not even that is happening. I think unionizing would help a lot and should definitely happen all over. Are people stretched so thin due to life choices that they are forced to take the crap and try to keep their jobs, because if they lose that job, then they don't have any savings? That seems so absurd for a skill set that is required for an animator for example. I know if I got a promotion, I wouldn't immediately get a more spacious house etc. because I could afford it but barely save anything, that's not a good thing. Though there are people who have put themselves in that situation as well. Best thing is to look for another, better place to work and then just one day you don't arrive to that crappy ex-workplace anymore. They don't deserve the notice or more of your time.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @chefrowlet
comment:
Shadows will probably sell fine thanks to the audience that doesn't care or pay attention to the issues around it, but man, it *needs* to bomb.

I think Ubi is done for regardless. The CEO was caught insider trading, deliberately driving down stock prices so he and his chinese partners could buy the minority shareholders out. They haven't had a new idea in ages and their quality has been backsliding... It's frustrating, I remember playing Division and seeing glimpses of brilliance through the muck of the general experience. Watch Dogs was a fantastic franchise that got kneecapped by presentation, with the underwhelming Legion kinda sealing the deal. Siege was once a great game, it had the potential to become a tentpole of the genre. Skull and Bones could've been a smash hit with the live service model keeping the lights on for years if it weren't for everything wrong with it. AC has been widely derided as repetitive and boring and Valhalla especially disappointed.

and yet Valhalla was their most profitable game to date afaik. It's a weird position.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @CmoIsDaNam3i
comment:
17:01 Imma push back a bit on the XDefiant part only because when it comes to the shooting part that really isn't true from my experience andany others

The gunplay and movement feel MUCH more akin to Call of Duty and frankly shockingly so as a guy who once loved CoD but fell off from all the non-sense in their games.  Last CoD game I enjoyed a lot was Black Ops 3 and last decent CoD IMHO was BO4.  But XDefiant for me does feel that same way when I look at the gameplay and how it plays and feels and really its been a refreshing thing personally.

Now netcode and other issues?  Makes sense but even then some of those issues seem to stem more from trying to use an engine not designed for FPS games, which can still check out what you are saying and heard but does have another thing often overlooked where you need to create systems and designs have to be built from the ground up to work first because the engine doesn't really suit it.  IIRC the Snowdrop engine (The engined used XDefiant) was more for MMOs than FPS games.  Maybe third person shooters at the most but that is still enough of a difference to make it so not everything will fit nicely.

Now again, not me trying to white knight Ubi here, just saying personal experience and many others but that doesn't seem quite right in the slightest when it comes to gunplay and similar feeling off.  And tons of others I think will say the same, even avid CoD players and YouTubers.

And no its not gonna be 1 for 1 the same, but I also wouldn't expect so when you use a different engine entirely from what CoD has been using tbh.

Just my two cents personally.  Love your work man and keep it up.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @jonnysmith549
comment: I work as a tool mechanic and make single parts. When i started working there 9 years ago we got a stack of drawings and just made whatever drawing was on top. Someone printed them from SAP and brought them to whoever was responsible for that kind of workpiece. 5 years ago we got a fancy new software and 3 people to service it while every person who used to just produce parts are now held back by trying to understand what time has to be reported on what workpiece and if all the data we need to work was in the system. All the fancy new software does is present a number to those who cant see what we do. However they never saw how much more efficient we were without reporting those numbers because there are no numbers to compare to. Trying to explain that i have to spend at least 2 of the 8 hours of work exclusively to report some bs numbers instead of confirming my work with the goddamn part i handed to the costumer...

As a brown dude, what I hate is people over correcting on this and going back to bigoted thinking where only straight white men are allowed to be main characters. 

The issue is bad writing, not that a brown person is on your screen. But so many people conflate the two, and just yell out straight racism and others act like they're making a good point. We don't have to ping pong between the two extremes. I wish people would approach this as what it is, a lot of different people with different ideas doing different things, some works some doesn't. Instead people tend to treat things like monoliths, and you have to accept everything or nothing about the monolith. It's very frustrating. 

This channel hasn't gone down the racist path, which is why I'm still here. I'm just saying you're standing at a rode that leads to a certain place. And far too many people take that road too easily. You can fight back against over correctness without promoting only straight white men into all visible positions.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @gatling216
comment:
I think there's some serious discussion to be had around the idea that all the online criticism, for any game, is just a bunch of right wing trolls. It's true that they're out there. It's true that if you try to include characters that fall outside their Overton window, they're going to scream about wokeness and DEI and everything else. Nothing is going to make that crowd happy, just like nothing is going to make the self righteous harpies on the other side happy. Being outraged is just about the only way to feel something in this day and age. 

The thing is, most gamers don't really care, so long as the game is good. BG3 is unabashedly queer from top to bottom, but first and foremost, it's a good game. A great game, even. Everything about its design, from top to bottom, was geared towards giving the players the freedom to experience the game however they wanted, and that resonated with basically everyone. On the other end of the spectrum, Elden Ring's Tarnished is barely a character. They're a tabula rasa upon which the player can imprint whatever they want, including nothing at all. And at the end of the day, no one seriously complained about the lack of diversity, because it's a good game. Helldivers brought an entire community together until Sony screwed it up by reveling in the hammy, dystopian vibes of Starship Troopers. No one cared that it was "problematic" because, say it with me now, it was a good game. 

That's all anyone can reasonably want or expect from developers. A good game doesn't have to match those first two in scope or scale. It can be big or small or single or multiplayer. You can pay once for everything or chuck in battle passes. The developer's philosophy on diversity or inclusiveness or whatever the hell else people rant about these days doesn't matter. Everything else is just window dressing. Honestly, I don't even think people would give a damn about DEI or SBI or whatever other three letter acronyms we're supposed to be mad about if they hadn't become shorthand for annoying and preachy.  If the end result is worth the asking price, people will pay it.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @tanysfoster2819
comment:
TL;DR Ubisoft & AC celebrated diversity from the very first release. The decline started immediately after the success of AC2 with cash-grab sequels, crunch, day-one DLC, MTX, fad-chasing, and all the other usual suspectes.  

I feel like this and other videos suffer from fundamental misattribution errors: you blame women, POC, and queer hires for "ruining" beloved franchises while being unaware of basic economics and politics. 

The really telling thing you said is, paraphrased as, "when people are worried about their jobs whenever they speak up, creativity suffers." The critical point you're missing is WHEN and WHO is doing the speaking. 

Translated, "when the white guys are afraid for their jobs, it's all over." Yeah, no shit. Bc they thought they were safe and only the women, POC, and queer folks were getting pushed out before. 

Here's a fact: financially successful companies don't hire women, POC, or queer employees except as a smokescreen. Often these people may be part of a company's foundation but they are quickly forced out when the company sees success. 

This is not to say that "white guys ruin everything" bc it doesn't come to that. Greed ruins everything and greed knows no boundaries.

Once a company is *already* circling the drain, they hire women, POC, and queer folks in a phenomenon called "glass floor." So-called "diversity hires" are attractive to investors late to the party bc private equity says they're good for growth. 

If the company isn't already terminal and diversity hires can put out the fires, they're forced out and the board of directors claims "diversity saved the day." If, as is more often the case, the company is too far gone, the fall is blamed on the diversity hire. Hence the term "glass floor."

comment: I look forward to re-watching this video again on Asmons channel üòÇ That pushing up juniors in place of seniors thing hits home for me. It's like a way to force compliance. Experienced and senior staff are more likely to push back on poor changes in direction, removing them and putting someone more junior in place looks good on a balance sheet as it usually means a saving in salary and someone following direction with more fresh energy as they're actively rising in their career. I've experienced this directly, the aim is to get someone who is 'on board' and if you have no idea what that role actually does, it might look like you succeeded on the surface, but the knowledge loss is real, you lost a lot of experience and knowledge of what got you to the dance when you binned that senior staffer. The quality and productivity drop is real, you just have to actually understand the job to see it.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @bellissimo4520
comment:
Ubisoft could never have fixed AC:Shadows to everyones acceptance; but what they COULD have done is:

- Admitting all the wrong / false stuff in the game (in terms of references to Japanese culture) and fixing them; also maybe removing some things that are considered tasteless by japanese people.
- Removing the stupid hip-hop music crap for Yasuke which, IMHO, isn't just an insult to Japanese culture, but also to black people (as if every black guy on this planet would be a hip-hop hood bro).
- Admitting that Yasuke probably wasn't actually a samurai in real life, and that they still wanted him as the main character, as a fictional, artistic interpretation of the events of that time.

That would still not have made everyone happy, not by a long shot... but it would at least have demonstrated an actual will to listed to criticism and show that their talk of respecting Japanese culture wasn't all just empty marketing talk.

Instead they doubled down and only made it all worse with their obvious double-speak non-apologies... well played, Ubisoft, well played...

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @nmtkawb
comment:
As a Japanese dude, at first I really didn't care that much about the "bending of history" part. I didn't mind Yasuke becoming samurai. I was like "bro it's a fucking Assassins' creed franchise. The game literally is about bending history. Plus Afro samurai best anime ever".
I'm sure you guys are already aware that every single western media that focused on any part of Asia always had a huge fuck ups of mixing cultures up, misrepresenting, and some what racism. And to be fair Japanese media has done the same to other cultures. It's hard to get things right if you are from other cultures. I'm fine with "Ok this shit's like 75% Japan at best".

But then Ubisoft started responding. Now they fucking messed up with that hard. The treatment of copyrighted designs and the disrespecting way of (not) resolving that, still trying to sound like they did their homework, and trying to misrepresent Japanese audience.
Like, disrespect the history all you want. That's the past. It's rude don't get me wrong, but I can cope with that. BUT DON'T disrespect us.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Katie-hb8iq
comment:
I think they need to close down every studio except for the Montreal, Quebec, and Paris studios. Massive Entertainment is a bit of a tricky one since it's been nearly five years since they did anything of note ‚Äî probably gut that too. Maybe keep the team that did the Prince of Persia Metroidvania because they actually made a good game at least, and keep Unfrozen around to do Heroes of Might and Magic for general goodwill. But generally, I don't understand why they need to invest in seven mobile games nobody cares about, along with five non-AC open-world games that basically play the same as each other. Ubisoft should focus on Just Dance, Tom Clancy, and Assassin's Creed for the most part. Just gut everything else. And yes, that also means Far Cry and Watch Dogs, that Toronto studio is botched and compromised with DEI like every other tech company in Toronto, and they haven't done anything of note for quite a long time.

This could cut down the company from 20,000 employees to likely 5000 or less, roughly the same size as Nintendo in Japan. You can't honestly tell me you need more employees than this when you look at the output of Nintendo. Instead of making 7 open world games, just pour it all into Assassin's Creed, similar to what Nintendo did with Zelda.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @jgj75
comment: Have you ever looked into the topic of educational polarization? In a nutshell, whether or not someone went to college has become a MASSIVE factor in determining someone's political leanings. I grew up working class, but then went to college and ended up in the big corporate world, so I am one of few who has lived both sides of this divide. Asmongold says that woke people are brainwashed, and college, grad school and the world of large corporations and firms is where that brainwashing occurs. If you haven't lived in that world, it's hard for you to comprehend how pervasive "the message" is to these people. Most of these people are not religious - "the message" IS their religion. I don't think a lot of these devs are even capable of making a game that appeals to gamers across cultural divides. It is possible (see Baldur's Gate 3), but difficult, especially if the developers continue to believe that creating products that don't conform to "the message" is essentially evil (remember, the message is their religion).

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @anarchicnerd666
comment:
so, this is an excellent report on the current state of Ubisoft and AC Shadows failing, but there's one thing i'd like to draw your attention too. in the video you glossed over "some former metoo allegations" and left it at that. i absolutely think that Ubisoft has overcorrected and focused on playing it safe, but i think it's worth remembering *exactly what they're overcorrecting from* - crucially the flurry of credible accusations of rhymes-with-grape, harassment and @$$Ault (plz no censor YT) leveled at senior management and executives as part of the abetterubisoft movement. the abetterubisoft hashtag is still searchable and spits out results, and the Jimquisition has some excellent videos on the subject. this is all stuff that happened 4 years ago, and resulted in Serge Hascoet being fired from Ubisoft and arrested by French police over the allegations, they were that serious.

otherwise excellent video

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @timoplays478
comment:
This video raises so many questions, first being where is your proof that any of this comes from *actual* Ubisoft employees?

Besides that, you contradict yourself in multiple ways throughout the video, one being how one of the employees ‚Äúclaims‚Äù that they can‚Äôt have bold & daring ideas yet Shadows is literally getting bombed with hate because they took a risk using a historical character as protagonist.

As for one of employees *claiming* that Ubisoft doesn‚Äôt listen to their fans, and have this toxic positivity, how do you explain that a game like Watch_Dogs 2 was literally made after devs contacted gamers, used AmA‚Äôs and so on to make a game that gamers actually want.

 Watch Dogs 2 came out in 2016, understood, a more recent example is Assassin‚Äôs Creed Mirage, in no way a perfect game however it‚Äôs literally tailored for the players in terms of gameplay, from parkour, stealth and a shorter story. 

Even besides mirage, shadows is literally tailored to the gamers who‚Äôve been begging for a return to form with Naoe, focusing on stealth & parkour, while yasuke is for the action oriented gamers.

It‚Äôs hilarious how you claim Ubisoft think they‚Äôre on the ‚Äúrighteous‚Äù path when the statement they put out literally had Yves admit that they KNOW they‚Äôre not on the right path, and will try and improve their efficacy as well as management. 

Does the delay of their biggest game not tell you that they‚Äôre aware of their wrong-doings and want to release a polished product? 

There‚Äôs a lot of bullshit being spewed throughout this video that‚Äôs hiding behind bold words, I won‚Äôt deny Ubisoft is sinking, however these *supposed* employees contradict what Ubisoft is aiming for.

comment:
Assassin's Creed as never been historically accurate, and we have people fighting over the term retainer vs samurai when come to find out many samurai were considered retainers. "Differences between samurai and retainers" copilot response. 
The terms ‚Äúsamurai‚Äù and ‚Äúretainer‚Äù are closely related but not identical. Here‚Äôs a breakdown of their differences:

Samurai
Role: Samurai were the military nobility and officer caste of medieval and early-modern Japan. They were skilled warriors who followed the code of Bushido, emphasizing honor, loyalty, and martial arts mastery1.
Status: Samurai held a higher social status and were often landowners or had significant influence in their domains1.
Duties: Their duties included serving their daimyo (feudal lords) in both military and administrative capacities1.
Retainer
Role: A retainer was a vassal who served a lord, often providing military services. In many cases, retainers were samurai, but not all retainers were of samurai rank2.
Status: Retainers could be of various social standings, including samurai, but their primary identity was tied to their service to a lord2.
Duties: Retainers were responsible for protecting their lords, managing estates, and performing various tasks as required by their position2.
In essence, while all samurai could be retainers, not all retainers were samurai. The term ‚Äúretainer‚Äù is more about the relationship and duty to a lord, whereas ‚Äúsamurai‚Äù refers to a specific class of warrior.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Translucent10
comment:
It's called living in Oceania 24/7. Orwell 1984. Woke friends and family network cronyism is a big part of the problem with quality among other things. And this....

Doublethink

‚ÄúTo know and not to know, to be conscious of complete truthfulness while telling carefully constructed lies, to hold simultaneously two opinions which cancelled out, knowing them to be contradictory and believing in both of them, to use logic against logic, to repudiate morality while laying claim to it, to believe that democracy was impossible and that the Party was the guardian of democracy, to forget whatever it was necessary to forget, then to draw it back into memory again at the moment when it was needed, and then promptly to forget it again: and above all, to apply the same process to the process itself -- that was the ultimate subtlety: consciously to induce unconsciousness, and then, once again, to become unconscious of the act of hypnosis you had just performed. Even to understand the word 'doublethink' involved the use of doublethink.‚Äù

"Doublethink means the power of holding two contradictory beliefs in one's mind simultaneously, and accepting both of them. The Party intellectual knows in which direction his memories must be altered; he therefore knows that he is playing tricks with reality; but by the exercise of doublethink he also satisfies himself that reality is not violated. The process has to be conscious, or it would not be carried out with sufficient precision, but it also has to be unconscious, or it would bring with it a feeling of falsity and hence of guilt. Doublethink lies at the very heart of Ingsoc, since the essential act of the Party is to use conscious deception while retaining the firmness of purpose that goes with complete honesty. To tell deliberate lies while genuinely believing in them, to forget any fact that has become inconvenient, and then, when it becomes necessary again, to draw it back from oblivion for just so long as it is needed, to deny the existence of objective reality and all the while to take account of the reality which one denies -- all this is indispensably necessary. Even in using the word doublethink it is necessary to exercise doublethink. For by using the word one admits that one is tampering with reality; by a fresh act of doublethink one erases this knowledge; and so on indefinitely, with the lie always one leap ahead of the truth. Ultimately it is by means of doublethink that the Party has been able -- and may, for all we know, continue to be able for thousands of years -- to arrest the course of history."

‚ÄúWho controls the past,‚Äô ran the Party slogan, ‚Äòcontrols the future: who controls the present controls the past.‚Äô And yet the past, though of its nature alterable, never had been altered. Whatever was true now was true from everlasting to everlasting. It was quite simple. All that was needed was an unending series of victories over your own memory. ‚ÄòReality control‚Äô, they called it: in Newspeak, ‚Äòdoublethink‚Äô.‚Äù 

‚ÄúOceanic society rests ultimately on the belief that Big Brother is omnipotent and that the Party is infallible. But since in reality Big Brother is not omnipotent and the party is not infallible, there is need for an unwearying, moment-to-moment flexibility in the treatment of facts. The keyword here is BLACKWHITE. Like so many Newspeak words, this word has two mutually contradictory meanings. Applied to an opponent, it means the habit of impudently claiming that black is white, in contradiction of the plain facts. Applied to a Party member, it means a loyal willingness to say that black is white when Party discipline demands this. But it means also the ability to BELIEVE that black is white, and more, to KNOW that black is white, and to forget that one has ever believed the contrary.‚Äù 

" ....that all written records agree with the orthodoxy of the moment is merely a mechanical act. But it is also necessary to remember that events happened in the desired manner. And if it is necessary to rearrange one's memories or to tamper with written records, then it is necessary to forget that one has done so. The trick of doing this can be learned like any other mental technique. It is learned by the majority of Party members, and certainly by all who are intelligent as well as orthodox. In Oldspeak it is called, quite frankly, 'reality control'. In Newspeak it is called doublethink, though doublethink comprises much else as well."

Orwell, 1984

comment:
What we are seeing is the use of primarily black people (fictional and real) as a kind of cultural weapon to destroy integrated societies with strong men. It isn't so much about the love of black men, but a hatred of nationalistic male leadership. My example for this is Black Panther 2. As soon as they could, they removed all the men and suddenly it's a matriarchy, where women hold all the key positions of leadership and do all the fighting and make all the decisions.

Here they couldn't do that exactly since they needed at least one male character. They couldn't do a white character because they hate white men. So they fixated on Yasuke. Why? He exists to demoralize Japanese men. If this were a western world, they would have chosen a woman or a trans person to demoralize western men. Black men? Use a black woman. The pattern is pretty easy to spot when you understand that the goal isn't to elevate any particular race. The goal is to smash male systems so that they can be remade by women for women, and there is a bigger goal about destroying the society's ability to ever operate cohesively.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @DeputyDerp
comment:
There's an additional irony to all this: as much as this word has been overused, this is... actually, for real this time, cultural appropriation. Not the benign kind, where some girl wears a qipao to prom and gets lambasted on the internet. I'm talking the malicious kind, where there is very much a monetary incentive to not give a shit about the source of iconography because of some opaque, nebulous marketing department decisions.

Case in point, all the things that AC Shadows used carelessly, like the Sekigahara Teppou Tai flag (that they didn't get permission for), the half-broken torii gate (a symbol of rememberance of the consequences of nuclear armaments, which Ubisoft used completely removed from its original context), and Yasuke using the Nobunaga family crest (found through Dashblue's video here:  /watch?v=rxydfYaAwjw , where Dashblue himself is Japanese-American and has a full-Japanese wife, where they point out that there are still living members of the Nobunaga family that have a legal claim to that crest and need to be asked permission to actually use it).

I don't think people really have a problem with representation in games, not even those that the media lambasts as "toxic gamers". Most just don't enjoy when representation muscles out the actual plot or effective storywriting, and especially don't like it when it's as rude and cynical as AC:Shadows.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Myrmidons
comment:
There are several reasons why Ubisoft is probably delaying the game:

1. Development needs: The game might need more time to develop. It's Bugisoft after all.

2. Feedback: The company might want to gather more player feedback before releasing the game. Ubisoft has received a lot of feedback and criticism. Personally, I received an email a couple of months ago and filled out a survey about whether I had pre-ordered the game and if not, why.

3. Community issues: The company might want to try to resolve community issues before releasing the game, which could lead to increased sales. There's been a lot of division among the AC fans (since 2017).

4. The most important reason is raising money. After the low review scores from fans and the terrible launches of big-budget games like Skull & Bones and Star Wars Outlaws, Ubi likely wants to raise money to help with development costs before releasing this game. This is why they are offering a free expansion now, and this is not because of the delay, but because their pre-orders are going poorly and the fans' reviews score are low.

In conclusion, Ubi is only delaying the inevitable after all the arrogance and ignorance they've shown to their customers in recent years. I have better things to do on Valentine's Day.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @Jonas_√¶
comment:
I am not at all surprised. 

I imagine it is like this:
The people at the very top of these companies likely have no clue and are just looking to satisfy shareholders. They are probably then advised by people in high positions and outsourced consultants who are ideologues who make decisions based on an ambition to make a greater cultural impact, first and foremost. Then you have the devs who either fall into one of two categories: those who share that ideological vision, and those who don't. Those who do happily tag along doing their part in "making a difference", while those who don't have to keep quiet and keep their heads down in order to not stand out among their co-workers ‚Äî while probably sharing a lot of the insightful criticism that would be necessary to voice.

Just my guess. Would be very typical in big companies like this even without the specific issue of ideological misguidance. Just the overall structure of these companies can lead to top-down tunnel vision.

title: I talked to Ubisoft Devs, it's far worse than we thought
author: @cokeycola9514
comment: The total dismissal of actual concerns about project management and narrative by just calling it "Western neckbeards screaming about DEI and Inclusivity" is the most frustrating part of the current gaming news cycle. There is an actual problem deep down here with toxic positivity, but dismissing it as "toxic gamer talk" is the REAL problem. We NEED to be able to have grown-up conversations about this. Yes, its uncomfortable and hard to navigate, but not its not just because there are more gay or black people in games. That is NOT the problem.
